conditional_answers.if_B: If inclusion as infected is close to universal and not materially influenced by baseline vulnerability, collider distortion is limited and the weak association would be more consistent with a small causal effect.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to collider bias from conditioning on infection status. We cannot tell whether the weak association reflects a true null effect or selection distortion without knowing whether mortality risk independently affects who gets detected as infected. If detection is strongly driven by baseline vulnerability, conditioning on infection can attenuate or flip the pollution-mortality association. If detection is largely independent of vulnerability, the within-infected estimate is more interpretable. Without that information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This is a collider trap. The analysis conditions on being detected as infected. If both PM2.5 exposure and mortality risk influence detection, conditioning can induce a spurious association or mask a real one. A weak association inside the infected-only cohort does not identify the causal effect in the target population.
classification: F1-T3 (Collider): conditioning on infection status can create or distort the pollution-mortality association.
pivotal_question: Is the probability of being included in the infected cohort influenced by baseline vulnerability that also predicts mortality, independently of pollution exposure?

scenario: A municipal health authority compares COVID-19 death rates between neighborhoods with historically high NO2 versus lower-NO2 suburbs using only hospitalized patients. In this hospitalized-only dataset, patients from high-NO2 areas have slightly lower 30-day mortality. The authority suggests traffic-related air pollution may be protective. Clinicians note that hospitalization depends on both exposure and baseline health, so restricting to hospitalized patients may condition on a common effect.
claim: Traffic-related NO2 exposure reduces COVID-19 mortality among hospitalized patients.
label: NO

variables.X: Long-term residential NO2 exposure
variables.Y: 30-day mortality risk for COVID-19
Z: Being hospitalized with COVID-19

causal_structure: X -> Z <- Y The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Hospitalization is a selection gate influenced by exposure and vulnerability.

conditional_answers.if_A: If frailty strongly increases hospitalization and mortality, conditioning on hospitalization can create an artificial negative association.
conditional_answers.if_B: If hospitalization is largely protocol-driven and unrelated to baseline mortality risk, collider bias is limited and other explanations would be needed.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to collider bias from conditioning on hospitalization. We cannot determine whether lower mortality in high-NO2 areas reflects a true protective effect or selection distortion without knowing how strongly baseline mortality risk influences hospitalization independent of NO2 exposure. If frailty strongly drives hospitalization, conditioning can generate a spurious negative association. If hospitalization is largely protocol-driven, the observed difference is more interpretable. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This is a collider bias failure. Hospitalization is conditioned on and can be influenced by both NO2 exposure and mortality risk. Conditioning can induce spurious negative associations or attenuate true positive effects, so an apparent protective association in hospitalized patients does not support a causal protective effect of NO2.
classification: F1-T3 (Collider): conditioning on hospitalization can create a spurious NO2-mortality relationship.
pivotal_question: Do baseline mortality risk factors substantially affect the chance of COVID-19 hospitalization independent of NO2 exposure?

scenario: During the first year of COVID-19 in Denmark, researchers estimate long-term PM2.5 exposure from residential histories and link it to deaths within 30 days of COVID-19. A surprising pattern appears when they analyze only people who both (i) had a PCR-confirmed infection and (ii) entered the hospital system for COVID-19-related care: within this double-restricted sample, the PM2.5-mortality association is much smaller than in general-population analyses. The team interprets this as evidence that air pollution mainly affects infection risk, not severity once people reach clinical care. But the inclusion rule is complex. High-pollution areas may increase the chance a person becomes infected and interacts with the health system (e.g., more respiratory symptoms leading to testing and referral). Separately, mortality risk is tied to baseline vulnerability and care pathways: frailer individuals may be hospitalized earlier, and those at highest risk may also be prioritized for rapid testing, ambulance transport, or admission during capacity constraints. If both pollution exposure and mortality risk shape who ends up in the "PCR-positive AND hospitalized" sample, then conditioning on this gatekeeper variable can create distortions that mimic attenuation, especially when comparing across waves with changing testing and admission practices.
claim: Air pollution affects COVID-19 infection risk but does not materially affect mortality among patients who reach hospital care.
label: NO

variables.X: Long-term residential PM2.5 exposure
variables.Y: COVID-19 30-day mortality risk
Z: Being included in the PCR-confirmed AND hospitalized patient cohort (selection gate)

causal_structure: X -> Z <- Y
key_insight: When the analytic sample is defined by a health-system gate (PCR-confirmed + hospitalized), that gate can be a collider influenced by both exposure and prognosis, making "attenuation" an unreliable mechanistic conclusion.
hidden_timestamp: Wave-dependent selection: 2020-03 to 2021-04 with changing testing/admission practices

conditional_answers.if_A: If prognosis strongly influences entry into the PCR-confirmed hospitalized cohort (e.g., high-risk individuals are preferentially tested, admitted, and therefore captured), then Y -> Z is strong. Since pollution can also increase entry (X -> Z), conditioning on Z can induce dependence between X and Y and pull the estimated PM2.5 effect on mortality toward the null, making the observed attenuation an artifact rather than a mechanism insight.
conditional_answers.if_B: If entry into the PCR-confirmed hospitalized cohort is driven mainly by administrative coverage and standardized criteria that do not depend on baseline prognosis (beyond measured adjustments), then Y -> Z is weak. In that case, the smaller association inside the selected cohort is less likely to be collider-driven and is more compatible with the interpretation that pollution contributes more to upstream infection risk than to downstream mortality once hospitalized.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to collider bias from conditioning on the combined PCR-confirmed and hospitalized inclusion criterion. We cannot tell whether the attenuated association reflects a true lack of effect on mortality in care or selection distortion without knowing whether mortality risk independently increases the probability of entering (and being recorded in) the hospitalized, PCR-confirmed cohort. If high-risk patients are more likely to be tested/admitted and pollution also increases entry, conditioning on that gate can drive the pollution-mortality association toward the null; if entry is independent of prognosis, the attenuation is more consistent with a smaller causal effect in that setting. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The claim relies on a comparison between general-population estimates and estimates within a doubly selected patient cohort. The selection variable Z = being observed in the PCR-positive and hospitalized dataset can be caused by both X (pollution exposure influencing infection/symptoms/care-seeking) and Y (mortality risk influencing triage, admission, and likelihood of being captured in hospital-based records). Conditioning on this collider can attenuate or otherwise distort the X-Y relationship, so the reduced association inside the selected cohort cannot be cleanly interpreted as evidence that pollution does not affect mortality once in care.
classification: F1-T3 (Collider): conditioning on a health-system inclusion gate can distort the pollution-mortality association.
pivotal_question: Across the study period, did baseline mortality risk (frailty/triage priority) materially increase the probability of being both PCR-confirmed and hospitalized, independent of pollution exposure?

subdomain: Climate extremes and disaster loss attribution
scenario: An analyst reviews decades of tropical cyclone loss records to assess whether climate change has increased disaster impacts. They rely on an international insurance catastrophe database that only includes events once they generate a reportable amount of insured damage because smaller events are inconsistently documented. They compute normalized insured losses using an exposure proxy for the affected areas and then restrict analysis to only the reportable events. In this restricted sample, seasons with higher landfall intensity anomalies appear to have lower normalized insured losses. The analyst argues this shows intensifying storms are not increasing damages and that preparedness is offsetting climate risk. However, the reportable-event filter may depend on both storm intensity and whether an event generates enough insured loss to cross the reporting threshold. Insurance coverage and exposed assets also vary across regions and over time, which can change the likelihood that a storm becomes reportable.
claim: More intense hurricane seasons reduce normalized insured losses, implying intensifying storms are not increasing damages.
label: NO

variables.X: Storm hazard intensity (e.g., landfall wind/precipitation intensity anomaly)
variables.Y: Normalized insured losses for the event or season (insured loss divided by an exposure proxy)
Z: Event is included as a "reportable" insured-loss case in the catastrophe database

causal_structure: X -> Z <- Y The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: When a dataset only contains events that cross a reporting threshold, the inclusion gate can create misleading relationships between storm intensity and normalized insured losses.
hidden_timestamp: Multi-decade loss record with time-varying reporting thresholds, insurance coverage, and exposed assets

conditional_answers.if_A: If becoming reportable depends jointly on storm intensity and on how large the insured loss is relative to the reporting cutoff, then restricting to reportable events conditions on a collider. Under this filter, very intense storms can appear even when normalized insured losses are relatively low, while less intense storms appear mainly when normalized insured losses are high enough to cross the cutoff. This can generate an artificial negative association between intensity anomalies and normalized insured losses in the restricted sample.
conditional_answers.if_B: If event inclusion is effectively complete or does not depend jointly on intensity and normalized insured losses, then conditioning on reportability is less likely to induce a spurious negative pattern. In that case, the observed association could be more consistent with real changes in exposure, vulnerability, or preparedness. The pattern would still not establish that intensity reduces losses without a design that identifies the causal effect.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to collider bias from conditioning on the reportable-event inclusion rule. We cannot determine whether the negative relationship reflects real changes in damages or a selection artifact without knowing whether an event becomes reportable based on both storm intensity and normalized insured losses crossing the reporting threshold. If reportability is jointly driven by intensity and losses, the negative pattern can be spurious. If reportability is not jointly driven by those factors, the pattern is more interpretable but still not causal evidence. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This analysis conditions on a collider. An event being included in the catastrophe database requires crossing a reportable insured-loss threshold. Storm intensity increases the chance an event is reportable, and higher normalized insured losses also increase the chance an event is reportable. Conditioning on being reportable can induce a spurious association between intensity and normalized insured losses within the observed sample. As a result, a negative relationship can appear even if greater intensity increases true damages in the full population of storms.
classification: This is an F1-T3 collider error: the analysis implicitly conditions on a common effect of X and Y (being recorded as a reportable loss event).
pivotal_question: Is an event included as a reportable insured-loss case because of both storm intensity and the magnitude of normalized insured losses relative to the reporting threshold, and did that rule change over time?

scenario: A research group uses GPS collars to study fallow deer movement between forest refuges and open meadows, focusing on whether deer exhibit area-restricted search (high sinuosity) when foraging in patchy food stations. To estimate sinuosity and detect area-restricted search, the team first "cleans" the telemetry data: they only keep individuals whose collars produced a high proportion of successful GPS fixes during twilight and night. In this landscape, fixes are more reliable when deer spend more time in open fields (clear sky view) and when their paths are relatively smooth/straight (fewer rapid turns and short step lengths that can coincide with missed or filtered points). After restricting to the high-fix subset, the team reports that deer spending more time in open meadows show lower sinuosity and concludes that open habitat leads to straighter, less area-restricted movement.
claim: Spending more time in open meadows causes deer to move in straighter paths (lower sinuosity).
label: NO

variables.X: Proportion of time the deer forages in open meadows (vs. forest cover) during the study window
variables.Y: True movement sinuosity / degree of area-restricted search during twilight and night
Z: Inclusion in the analyzed dataset after requiring high GPS-fix success and applying filtering

causal_structure: X -> Z <- Y (conditioning on Z)
key_insight: When inclusion requires both frequent meadow use and trajectories that survive filtering, the retained sample can create a relationship between meadow use and sinuosity that is not causal.
hidden_timestamp: Study window in which selection occurs during GPS fixing and trajectory cleaning for twilight and night data

conditional_answers.if_A: If the cleaning rule preferentially excludes trajectories with frequent sharp turns and short steps, then movement sinuosity affects whether a deer is retained, along with meadow use affecting fix success. Conditioning on retention can induce a negative association, so the conclusion that meadow use causes straighter movement may largely reflect which trajectories were kept.
conditional_answers.if_B: If retention is driven mainly by habitat-related fix conditions and is not meaningfully affected by turning-heavy movement after filtering settings are fixed, then the induced collider effect is weaker. In that case, the observed association is less likely to be manufactured by selection, though it still would not establish causality without additional design.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to collider bias from conditioning on inclusion after GPS-fix and filtering requirements. We cannot determine whether meadow use truly reduces sinuosity or whether both meadow use and low sinuosity simply increase the chance a trajectory is retained without knowing how the retention rule depends on movement geometry versus habitat. If turning-heavy paths are disproportionately excluded, the observed association can be spurious. If retention is essentially unrelated to sinuosity after accounting for habitat, the association is more interpretable. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The analysis conditions on being included in the retained telemetry dataset, which is a non-random inclusion gate. Meadow use increases GPS fix success and retention, and true movement sinuosity can also affect whether trajectories pass the cleaning threshold. Conditioning on the inclusion gate can induce a spurious association between meadow use and sinuosity, making meadow users appear to have straighter paths even if habitat does not causally change movement sinuosity.
classification: Non-random inclusion into the analyzed telemetry dataset (selection on track quality) threatens causal validity.
pivotal_question: Does the retention rule exclude high-sinuosity trajectories even when deer use the same habitats and collars have similar fix conditions?

scenario: A conservation agency funds a study to understand whether deer that are more tolerant of human disturbance have different space-use patterns. Field staff capture deer using baited traps near forest edges and fit them with relatively heavy GPS store-on-board collars that must later be recovered. During analysis, researchers restrict attention to the collared subset because only those animals have detailed trajectories. They then report an empirical pattern: among collared deer, individuals classified as "bolder" during capture/handling (e.g., less struggle, quicker approach to bait) tend to have smaller estimated home ranges, and the report concludes that boldness leads deer to remain in tighter, more localized ranges. However, in this system, the probability of being captured and collared is higher for deer that readily approach bait (related to boldness) and also higher for deer whose normal ranging keeps them near the trapping corridor (smaller home ranges are more likely to overlap the trap grid).
claim: Greater boldness toward humans causes deer to have smaller home ranges.
label: NO

variables.X: Boldness / tolerance to human disturbance (propensity to approach bait and struggle less during capture)
variables.Y: True home-range size (space-use extent) during the study season
Z: Inclusion in the observed telemetry sample by being captured and fitted with a collar

causal_structure: X -> Z <- Y (conditioning on Z)
key_insight: When both boldness and true home-range size affect who gets collared, the collared subset can show relationships that do not hold in the full population.
hidden_timestamp: Capture and collaring period with subsequent collar recovery that limits which animals contribute trajectories

conditional_answers.if_A: If larger-ranging deer are less likely to be captured because they spend less time in the trapping corridor, then true home-range size strongly affects inclusion along with boldness. Conditioning on inclusion can create an apparent negative relationship even if boldness does not causally shrink home ranges.
conditional_answers.if_B: If capture probability is similar across home-range sizes because the trap grid covers most ranges or effort is spatially comprehensive, then the effect of home-range size on inclusion is weaker and the induced collider effect is smaller. The observed association would be less likely to be purely selection-induced, though it still would not establish causality without additional design or evidence.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to collider bias from conditioning on captured-and-collared inclusion. We cannot determine whether boldness truly reduces home-range size or whether bold and small-ranging deer are simply more likely to be captured without knowing how capture probability varies with home-range size in the full population. If capture strongly favors small-ranging animals regardless of boldness, the association can be induced by selection. If capture is effectively unrelated to home-range size given the trap placement, the association is more interpretable. Without this information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The claim is drawn from a non-representative sample because only captured-and-collared deer are observed. Boldness influences capture probability, and true home-range size can also influence capture probability because trapping occurs in a limited corridor. Conditioning on being captured and collared can induce a spurious association between boldness and home-range size, so the observed pattern among collared deer need not reflect a causal effect of boldness on home-range size.
classification: Non-random sampling into the collared group (capture-based inclusion) threatens causal validity.
pivotal_question: With the same trap placement and effort, are deer with larger true home ranges substantially less likely to be captured and collared than small-ranging deer?

scenario: A coastal agency evaluates tributyltin (TBT) contamination in a busy bay with a major port. Because sampling is expensive, the team chooses sites that are close to shipping lanes and marinas and that have recent reports of imposex in local snails from citizen-science groups. They analyze only the selected sites and publish a map showing that higher vessel traffic areas have higher TBT in sediments. In the dataset, distance to the port and measured TBT levels are strongly correlated. However, site inclusion was not random. Permits and logistics are easiest in port-managed areas, which often have high traffic. The agency also prioritized locations where prior biological alerts suggested contamination. The association is computed only among the chosen sites, and the report treats it as evidence that traffic intensity is driving TBT levels across the bay.
claim: High vessel traffic causes higher TBT contamination in bay sediments.
label: NO

variables.X: Vessel traffic intensity near a site (e.g., proximity to port/marinas/shipping lanes)
variables.Y: Measured TBT concentration in surface sediments
Z: Site is included in the monitoring dataset after being selected for sampling

causal_structure: X -> Z <- Y (conditioning on Z)
key_insight: When both traffic proximity and contamination-related alerts affect which sites are sampled, the sampled subset can manufacture an apparent traffic to contamination gradient.
hidden_timestamp: Site targeting based on logistics and recent biological alerts at the time of sampling and site selection

conditional_answers.if_A: If the same relationship appears under a pre-registered sampling design that includes sites regardless of prior alerts and logistical ease, then the observed gradient is less likely to be created by conditioning on the selection rule. That would make the claim more plausible, though it would still require careful identification.
conditional_answers.if_B: If the relationship weakens, reverses, or becomes highly heterogeneous once low-alert and logistically difficult sites are included, then the original association was partly created by the inclusion rule. In that case, the published map reflects the targeting strategy more than a bay-wide causal effect of traffic on sediment TBT.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to collider bias from conditioning on non-random site selection. We cannot determine whether vessel traffic truly raises sediment TBT levels across the bay or whether the pattern is induced by selecting sites based on both traffic proximity and prior contamination alerts. If a broader design-based sample shows the same gradient, the claim becomes more plausible. If the gradient weakens or disappears when low-priority sites are included, the observed pattern was largely selection-driven. Without information about the excluded sites or the selection mechanism, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This analysis conditions on an inclusion gate because only selected sites are observed. Site selection is influenced by vessel-traffic proximity and by contamination-related signals correlated with measured TBT. Conditioning on being selected can induce or amplify an association between traffic intensity and measured TBT within the observed dataset, even if the bay-wide relationship is different. Without evidence from excluded sites or a known selection model, the causal claim is not justified from the observed sample.
classification: Non-random inclusion of sampling sites can induce a misleading exposure-contaminant association.
pivotal_question: Under a pre-registered sampling plan that includes low-alert and logistically difficult sites, would the vessel-traffic and sediment TBT relationship still hold?

scenario: Researchers study UV-filter contamination (from sunscreens) in coastal surface waters during the summer tourist season. To maximize detection, they schedule sampling during mid-day high-use hours and choose beaches that are easy to access, have lifeguard infrastructure, and are flagged as "hotspots" in prior press reports about chemical pollution. They then compare sites and find that beaches with higher estimated visitor density have higher concentrations of UV filters in grab water samples. The paper's discussion frames this as evidence that higher beachgoer density is causing higher UV-filter contamination. But the monitoring campaign's inclusion criteria mean the dataset largely consists of crowded, accessible, previously flagged beaches; sparsely visited or logistically difficult sites are rarely sampled. The correlation is computed only among the sites that made it into the study.
claim: Higher beachgoer density causes higher UV-filter contamination in coastal waters.
label: NO

variables.X: Beachgoer density / swimmer load at a site-time
variables.Y: Measured UV-filter concentration in coastal surface water
Z: S: Beach-site is included in the monitoring dataset (selected for sampling)

causal_structure: The analysis conditions on a beach being included in the monitoring dataset. Inclusion is influenced by beachgoer density cues and by outcome-related pollution suspicion from prior hotspot reporting. This makes inclusion a collider that can induce an association between density and measured contamination within the included subset.
key_insight: When inclusion depends on both density cues and pollution-related hotspot flags, analyzing only included beaches can create an apparent dose response even if the coastline-wide pattern is weaker or different.
hidden_timestamp: During study design and site selection, before water samples are collected and analyzed, the inclusion rule determines which beaches enter the dataset.

conditional_answers.if_A: If beaches would have been included regardless of prior pollution hotspot flags and logistical ease, then inclusion is not acting like a collider driven by outcome-related selection. In that setting, a persistent positive association between density and measured UV-filter concentration is more consistent with a causal effect of higher swimmer load increasing short-term inputs and concentrations.
conditional_answers.if_B: If beach inclusion is influenced by outcome-related hotspot suspicion or other cues that track true contamination, then inclusion is a collider driven by both density cues and pollution-related selection. In that setting, the positive association among included beaches can be largely selection-induced and may not reflect the coastline-wide causal effect.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a T3 collider created by conditioning on which beaches were included in the monitoring dataset. We cannot determine whether density causes higher UV-filter contamination or whether the association is induced because inclusion depends on both density cues and pollution-related hotspot selection. If inclusion is outcome-blind and does not depend on pollution suspicion, then a persistent association would better support the causal interpretation. If inclusion depends on pollution-related selection, then the association can be spurious within the included subset. Without clear information on the inclusion rule and excluded beaches, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The reported relationship is computed only among beaches that were included for sampling. If inclusion is influenced by beachgoer density cues and also by pollution-related hotspot flags that track true contamination, then conditioning on inclusion creates a collider. Conditioning on a collider can induce or inflate an association between density and measured UV-filter concentration even when the broader coastline would show a weaker or different pattern. Without data on excluded beaches and explicit inclusion mechanisms, the causal claim is not warranted.
classification: Convenience sampling of sites can create a misleading association when inclusion depends on both exposure cues and outcome-related flags.
pivotal_question: Did the beach inclusion rule depend on pollution-related hotspot suspicion or other outcome-related cues, and would the density to UV-filter association remain under an outcome-blind sampling design that also includes low-use and hard-to-access beaches?

scenario: A multi-residue monitoring project compares pharmaceutical contamination across estuarine stations. Each station collects a grab water sample and sends it to a central lab. The lab publishes only results that pass strict QA/QC: acceptable surrogate recovery, no severe matrix effects, and quantification above reporting limits. In practice, samples from high-turbidity stations often fail recovery (more interferences), and samples with very low true concentrations often fall below quantification and are omitted from the final dataset. The published report then shows that "clear-water stations have higher pharmaceutical concentrations than turbid stations," and it speculates that turbidity reduces contamination or speeds degradation. The key detail is that the public dataset is conditioned on being reportable (passing QA/QC). Both turbidity (which affects whether the lab can report a value) and the true concentration (which affects whether the analyte clears detection/quantification) influence whether a station appears in the final table.
claim: Lower turbidity causes higher pharmaceutical concentrations in estuarine surface waters.
label: NO

variables.X: Water turbidity / matrix complexity affecting analytical recoveries
variables.Y: True pharmaceutical concentration in the water sample
Z: S: Measurement is included in the published dataset (passes QA/QC and quantification)

causal_structure: The analysis conditions on a measurement being reported in the published dataset. Reportability is influenced by turbidity through analytical recoveries and by true concentration through detection and quantification. Conditioning on this reportability gate makes it a collider that can induce a negative association between turbidity and reported concentration.
key_insight: When both matrix-driven reportability and true concentration determine which results are published, the reported dataset can show a relationship that is created by the reporting filter rather than by causation.
hidden_timestamp: After sampling, during laboratory quality control and reporting, the reportability gate determines which station results appear in the published dataset.

conditional_answers.if_A: If the analysis properly incorporates failed quality control results and low-concentration non-detects, and the same turbidity to concentration pattern remains, then the conclusion does not rely on conditioning on reportable results alone. In that setting, the association is more consistent with real station differences correlated with turbidity rather than a pure reporting artifact.
conditional_answers.if_B: If the pattern shrinks, disappears, or reverses once quality control failures and non-detects are incorporated, then the published relationship was induced by conditioning on reportability. In that setting, reportability acts as a collider influenced by both turbidity and true concentration, and the negative association in the published table is not evidence of a causal turbidity effect.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a T3 collider created by conditioning on which measurements were reportable and published. We cannot determine whether turbidity causes higher or lower pharmaceutical concentrations without knowing how many results were excluded and how exclusion depended on both turbidity-related analytical failure and true concentration. If the same relationship holds after modeling or recovering excluded results, the causal interpretation is more credible. If the relationship changes once excluded results are accounted for, the published association was selection-induced. Without the missing measurements and the reporting mechanism, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Inclusion in the published dataset depends on a reportability gate. If turbidity affects reportability through matrix effects and true concentration affects reportability through detectability, then reportability is a collider influenced by both X and Y. Conditioning on this collider can induce a spurious association between turbidity and reported concentration among published results, including apparent sign reversals. Without the excluded results and explicit information about the reporting rule, the causal claim about turbidity is not supported.
classification: Non-random inclusion into the reported dataset can induce a misleading association when both exposure conditions and outcome magnitude affect reportability.
pivotal_question: If the team incorporated the omitted quality control failures and non-detects, or re-measured them with a turbidity-robust method, would the turbidity to concentration relationship remain?

scenario: A national soil-monitoring program reports a striking pattern in its 10-year summaries. Among the monitoring sites that were kept in the "consistent time-series" analysis (i.e., sites with complete records, no flagged sampling irregularities, and metadata judged sufficient for QA/QC), farms that adopted organic management show larger declines in topsoil Cu than farms that stayed conventional. The report highlights that several sites were excluded from the consistent subset because they had missing campaigns, were replaced by nearby sites during network reorganization, or were flagged for protocol changes (e.g., sampling depth issues) that made trends hard to interpret. The public-facing interpretation is that organic transition improves soil quality. But practitioners note that being included in the consistent subset depends both on management status (organic farms often provide more complete field logs) and on whether the observed Cu trajectory looks "plausible" under the monitoring protocol (extreme increases or suspicious jumps are more likely to be investigated, reclassified, or dropped from the clean trend analysis).
claim: Switching to organic farming causes Cu levels in topsoil to decline.
label: NO

variables.X: Organic transition status of the farm/site (adopted organic vs not)
variables.Y: Observed 10-year change in topsoil Cu concentration at the site
Z: Site included in the "consistent/QA-passing" time-series subset used for trend reporting

causal_structure: The reported trend comparison conditions on a site being retained in the consistent time-series subset. Retention can be influenced by organic status through documentation and by the observed Cu trajectory through plausibility screening and exclusion. Conditioning on this retention filter makes it a collider that can induce an association between organic transition and Cu change within retained sites.
key_insight: If the consistent subset retains well-documented sites and drops sites with suspicious Cu jumps, and both of these depend on exposure and outcome, the retained comparison can manufacture an apparent organic benefit.
hidden_timestamp: After measurements are collected, during quality review and construction of the consistent time-series subset, the retention rule determines which sites enter the reported trend analysis.

conditional_answers.if_A: If retention in the consistent subset does not depend on the observed Cu trajectory, or if the organic to Cu pattern is the same when using the full monitoring frame, then conditioning on retention is less likely to be creating the association. In that setting, the observed difference is more consistent with a real difference between organic and conventional sites, while still remaining observational evidence.
conditional_answers.if_B: If retention depends on both organic status and the observed Cu trajectory, such as excluding extreme increases or suspicious jumps more often in one group, then retention is a collider. In that setting, the apparent organic benefit can be selection-induced and may not reflect a causal effect of switching to organic farming.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a T3 collider created by conditioning on inclusion in the consistent time-series subset. We cannot determine whether organic transition causes Cu declines or whether the association is induced by retention rules that depend on both documentation and the observed Cu trajectory. If retention is independent of Cu change and the pattern holds in the full dataset, the causal interpretation is more credible. If retention depends on Cu trajectories, the association among retained sites can be spurious. Without clear information on the retention mechanism and excluded sites, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The reported association is computed within a restricted subset of sites retained for consistent trend reporting. If organic transition affects retention through documentation and the observed Cu trajectory affects retention through plausibility screening, then retention is a collider influenced by both X and Y. Conditioning on this collider can induce a spurious association between organic status and Cu change, even if organic management has no causal effect on Cu. Without demonstrating the pattern in the unrestricted monitoring frame and without validating that retention does not depend on observed Cu trajectories, the causal claim is not warranted.
classification: Selection-on-a-collider: the analysis conditions on an inclusion/consistency variable affected by both exposure and outcome.
pivotal_question: Did retention in the consistent time-series subset depend on the observed Cu trajectory, such as excluding extreme or suspicious Cu changes, and does the organic to Cu relationship persist in the full dataset without the retention filter?

scenario: A soil contamination agency introduces a stricter QA/QC rule mid-program: only site-year measurements that pass a "metadata completeness" audit are used in official trend dashboards. The audit score is partly driven by how well the site manager documents boundary conditions (e.g., tillage depth, land-use changes, sampling depth) and partly by whether the lab and field teams can reconcile the measurement with expected ranges (large unexplained jumps trigger special reviews and may be withheld from the dashboard pending investigation). After the rule change, analysts notice that sites near industrial zones show *smaller* reported increases in Pb over time than rural reference sites, and they credit recent emission controls near industry. Internally, staff point out that industrial-proximate sites receive more attention and often have better documentation, while measurements showing strong Pb increases are more likely to be held back as "inconsistent" until the cause is clarified (e.g., suspected sampling depth mismatch or reclassification of the site's land-use category). The agency's public claim is that industrial adjacency is becoming protective against Pb accumulation.
claim: Living near industrial areas now reduces Pb accumulation in topsoil.
label: NO

variables.X: Industrial proximity of the monitoring site (near industrial zone vs rural reference)
variables.Y: Observed change in topsoil Pb concentration over time at the site
Z: Record included in the official dashboard after passing the metadata completeness/QA-QC audit

causal_structure: The reported dashboard trends condition on a record passing the audit and being included in the dashboard. Audit inclusion can be influenced by industrial proximity through documentation attention and by the observed Pb change through withholding of large jumps. Conditioning on this inclusion gate makes it a collider that can induce an apparent protective association for industrial proximity among included records.
key_insight: When inclusion in the public dashboard depends on both the exposure setting and the observed outcome trajectory, the reported relationship can be created by the inclusion filter rather than by causation.
hidden_timestamp: After measurements are taken, during audit review and dashboard publication, the inclusion decision determines which records enter the public trend analysis.

conditional_answers.if_A: If audit inclusion and withholding are independent of the observed Pb change, and the industrial proximity to Pb trend appears similarly in the raw data before filtering, then conditioning on inclusion is less likely to be creating the negative association. In that setting, the pattern is more consistent with real differences that coincide with industrial proximity, while still remaining observational evidence.
conditional_answers.if_B: If records with large Pb increases are more likely to fail the audit or be withheld, and this process differs by industrial proximity, then inclusion is a collider influenced by both X and Y. In that setting, the apparent protective association can be selection-induced and is not evidence that living near industry reduces Pb accumulation.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a T3 collider created by conditioning on audit-passing inclusion in the public dashboard. We cannot determine whether industrial proximity reduces Pb accumulation or whether the association is induced by an inclusion rule that depends on both industrial proximity and the observed Pb change. If inclusion is independent of Pb trajectories and the pattern holds before filtering, the causal interpretation is more credible. If large Pb increases are preferentially withheld or fail audit in a way related to proximity, the association can be spurious among included records. Without clear information on withholding and audit dependence on Pb changes, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The dashboard analysis is restricted to records that pass the audit and are included in the public dashboard. If industrial proximity influences inclusion through documentation attention and the observed Pb change influences inclusion through withholding or audit failure, then inclusion is a collider influenced by both X and Y. Conditioning on this collider can induce a negative association that looks like a protective effect even when no such causal effect exists. Without the excluded records and the audit and withholding mechanism, the causal claim is not supported.
classification: Collider bias from conditioning on a QA/QC inclusion variable affected by both exposure setting and observed contamination change.
pivotal_question: Do records with large Pb increases fail the audit or get withheld more often, and does that inclusion process differ between industrial-proximate and rural sites?

scenario: During a reorganization of a long-running soil contamination network, several vineyard monitoring locations are replaced or merged with nearby sites to maintain coverage. Official communications emphasize that the program is improving "consistency" by standardizing protocols and pruning problematic series. In the next report, the remaining vineyard sites show a strong negative relationship between deep ploughing events and 10-year topsoil Cu change: vineyards that reported deep ploughing tend to show the largest Cu declines. The report presents this as evidence that deep ploughing is an effective remediation practice for Cu-contaminated topsoils. Field staff note, however, that the vineyards that undergo deep ploughing are also the ones that most reliably report tillage depth and related metadata, while sites with extreme Cu changes (especially abrupt increases or erratic jumps) are disproportionately likely to be reclassified as "inconsistent," temporarily withheld from trend summaries, or replaced by a new nearby monitoring point. Because the reorganization occurred alongside shifting farming types and site management changes, it is hard to tell whether the observed deep-ploughing pattern is a real dilution process, a reporting artifact, or a selection effect from which vineyards remain in the final vineyard trend set.
claim: Deep ploughing causes Cu contamination in vineyard topsoil to decrease over the next decade.
label: NO

variables.X: Deep ploughing occurrence and documentation at vineyard sites
variables.Y: Observed 10-year change in topsoil Cu concentration at vineyard sites
Z: Vineyard series retained in the post-reorganization 'consistent' dataset used for official trend analysis

causal_structure: The reported comparison conditions on a vineyard time series being retained in the post-reorganization consistent dataset. Retention can be influenced by deep ploughing documentation and by the observed Cu trajectory through pruning, withholding, and site replacement. Conditioning on retention makes it a collider that can induce an apparent remediation association among retained vineyards.
key_insight: If the network retains well-documented ploughed vineyards and removes vineyards with problematic Cu trajectories, and both depend on exposure and outcome, the retained set can create a false remediation signal.
hidden_timestamp: During network reorganization and subsequent pruning of time series for the official trend set, the retention and replacement decisions determine which vineyards enter the analysis.

conditional_answers.if_A: If retention and replacement decisions are independent of the observed Cu trajectory, and the deep ploughing to Cu pattern is similar before pruning, then conditioning on retention is less likely to be creating the association. In that setting, the negative relationship is more consistent with a real measured difference linked to deep ploughing, while still remaining observational evidence.
conditional_answers.if_B: If vineyards with extreme or erratic Cu changes are more likely to be withheld, reclassified, or replaced, and this process differs between ploughed and non-ploughed vineyards, then retention is a collider influenced by both X and Y. In that setting, the apparent remediation association can be selection-induced and is not evidence that deep ploughing causes Cu declines.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to a T3 collider created by conditioning on which vineyard series were retained after reorganization. We cannot determine whether deep ploughing causes Cu declines or whether the association is induced by retention and replacement rules that depend on both ploughing documentation and the observed Cu trajectory. If retention is independent of Cu changes and the pattern holds before pruning, the causal interpretation is more credible. If retention depends on Cu trajectories in a way related to ploughing status, the association among retained vineyards can be spurious. Without clear information on retention and replacement mechanisms, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: The reported relationship is computed among vineyards retained in the official post-reorganization trend set. If deep ploughing affects retention through documentation and the observed Cu change affects retention through pruning, withholding, or replacement, then retention is a collider influenced by both X and Y. Conditioning on this collider can induce an apparent negative association that resembles remediation even when no causal effect exists. Without the excluded or replaced series and the retention mechanism, the causal claim about deep ploughing is not supported.
classification: Collider bias via conditioning on a 'retained as consistent vineyard series' variable affected by both the management practice and the observed contaminant trend.
pivotal_question: Were vineyards with extreme or erratic Cu trajectories more likely to be withheld, reclassified, or replaced, and did that retention process differ between ploughed and non-ploughed vineyards in the trend set?

scenario: A regional forest agency evaluates a thinning program intended to reduce wildfire risk in mixed conifer stands. Analysts assemble multi year monitoring data and label a stand as treated for a given year if the stand is thinned at any point during that year. Songbird abundance is measured during the breeding season and summarized across the full year. Some stands are thinned late in the year after a separate monitoring review is completed, while others are never thinned. The public summary compares annual bird counts between stands labeled treated versus untreated and reports that treated stands have lower bird counts. The summary does not state whether bird counts recorded before the thinning date were attributed to the treated label for stands that were thinned later in the year.
claim: Forest thinning reduces songbird abundance in treated stands.
label: NO

variables.X: Forest thinning treatment (stand is thinned in a given year)
variables.Y: Songbird abundance (counts/detections during breeding season)
Z: Pre thinning interval within the year that is later attributed to the treated label for stands thinned later

causal_structure: The analysis labels a stand as treated based on a future thinning date and may attribute earlier bird observations to the treated period.
key_insight: When exposure is defined using a future event within the observation window, pre exposure time can be misattributed to the exposed group and distort the estimated effect.
hidden_timestamp: Whether bird observations occurring before the thinning date were counted under the treated label for stands that were thinned later in the year.

conditional_answers.if_A: If bird counts from before the thinning date were attributed to the treated label for stands thinned later, then the treated group includes a misclassified pre thinning interval. That coding can manufacture differences because outcomes that occurred before treatment are being counted as if they occurred after treatment. Under this interpretation, the comparison does not identify a causal effect of thinning on birds.
conditional_answers.if_B: If treated time began only at the actual thinning date and bird counts were compared in aligned post thinning windows, then the misclassification mechanism is reduced. A remaining difference would be more consistent with a treatment effect, although non random placement and other biases could still remain. Under this interpretation, the design is closer to supporting the claim.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to immortal time bias. We cannot determine whether thinning caused lower bird counts or whether the result is driven by attributing pre thinning observations to the treated label without knowing how outcomes before the thinning date were coded. If pre thinning observations were counted under the treated label, the comparison does not identify a causal effect. If exposure started at the thinning date with aligned post thinning follow up, the association is more consistent with a causal interpretation. Without this timing and coding information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Labeling a stand as treated based on whether it is thinned at any point during the year can create a time misclassification problem. If bird observations from before the thinning date are attributed to the treated period for stands that are thinned later, then outcomes are being assigned to exposure that had not yet occurred. That distortion can produce apparent differences that do not reflect a causal effect of thinning. The causal conclusion therefore depends on the exact timing rule for when treated status begins and how pre thinning observations are handled.
classification: Direction error: reverse causality (claimed X -> Y, plausible Y -> X).
pivotal_question: For stands thinned later in the year, were bird counts recorded before the thinning date included under the treated label or treated as unexposed time?

scenario: Several rural counties track wolf livestock conflict and management actions over time. In a public dashboard, the counties label a year as exposed if any authorized lethal removals occur at some point during that year. Depredations are tallied across the full calendar year from reports and confirmations. The dashboard shows that years labeled exposed have more depredations than years labeled unexposed, and a stakeholder group argues removals make the problem worse. Removals are typically authorized only after depredations rise and documentation is completed, so the first removal often occurs weeks into the year. The summary does not clarify whether depredations that occurred before the first removal were counted under the exposed label for years that later had removals.
claim: Increased wolf removal causes more livestock depredations.
label: NO

variables.X: Wolf removal intensity (number of wolves removed / authorizations executed)
variables.Y: Livestock depredations (reported/confirmed losses)
Z: Pre removal interval within the year before the first authorized removal that may be attributed to the exposed label

causal_structure: The analysis defines exposure using a future removal event within the year and may attribute earlier depredations to the exposed period.
key_insight: When exposure is defined by a later action, outcomes that occur before the action can be misassigned to the exposed group and create a misleading association.
hidden_timestamp: Whether depredations occurring before the first removal action in a year were counted under the exposed label for years that later had removals.

conditional_answers.if_A: If depredations from before the first removal were counted under the exposed label for years that later had removals, then the analysis assigns pre exposure outcomes to exposure. That time misclassification can make removal years appear to have more depredations even if removals had no harmful effect. Under this interpretation, the dashboard pattern does not identify a causal effect of removal on depredations.
conditional_answers.if_B: If exposure began only at the first removal date and depredations were compared in aligned post removal windows, then the misclassification mechanism is reduced. A remaining increase after the start of removals would be more consistent with a harmful effect, although other observational biases could still remain. Under this interpretation, the evidence is closer to supporting the claim.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to immortal time bias. We cannot determine whether removals increased depredations or whether the pattern is driven by attributing pre removal depredations to the exposed label without knowing how depredations before the first removal were coded. If pre removal depredations were counted as exposed, the association can be an artifact. If exposure started at the first removal date with aligned follow up, the association is more consistent with a causal interpretation. Without this timing and coding information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: Using an ever exposed definition within a calendar year can misclassify time. If a year is labeled exposed because removals occur later, then depredations that happened before removals can be assigned to exposure even though the intervention had not yet occurred. That distortion can produce a positive association between removal intensity and depredations without identifying a causal increase. The causal conclusion therefore depends on whether risk time and events prior to the first removal are treated as unexposed or are incorrectly attributed to the exposed group.
classification: Direction error: reverse causality (claimed X -> Y, plausible Y -> X).
pivotal_question: In years with removals, were depredations that occurred before the first removal action counted under the exposed label or treated as unexposed time?

scenario: A district health office evaluates a point of use chlorination program for household drinking water in rural villages. Households enroll at the start of the rainy season, but the chlorine dispenser and training are delivered later during a scheduled visit, typically 6 to 10 weeks after enrollment. The report labels a household as treated if it eventually receives the dispenser at any point during the season and untreated if it never receives it. Diarrhoea incidence in children under 5 is recorded weekly starting at enrollment. The report compares the full season diarrhoea burden between households ever labeled treated versus never treated. The summary does not clarify whether diarrhoea episodes that occurred before the delivery visit were attributed to the treated group for households that received the dispenser later.
claim: Receiving the household chlorination kit caused a large reduction in under-5 diarrhoea during the rainy season.
label: NO

variables.X: Classified as receiving the chlorination kit (treated group membership)
variables.Y: Under-5 diarrhoea episodes recorded during follow-up
Z: Immortal pre-delivery interval (must remain enrolled until delivery date)

causal_structure: Treated status is defined by a later delivery event and earlier follow up time may be attributed to the treated label.
key_insight: If treated status is defined using future receipt, pre delivery time can be misclassified as treated and create a spurious effect.
hidden_timestamp: Whether follow up time and episodes before the delivery visit were counted under the treated label for households that received the kit later.

conditional_answers.if_A: If follow up time before delivery was counted under the treated label for households that received the kit later, then the treated group includes a misclassified pre delivery interval. Episodes that occurred before exposure would be assigned to treated time, and households with early events or dropout could be unevenly represented across groups. Under this interpretation, the reported reduction can be a design artifact rather than a causal effect.
conditional_answers.if_B: If exposure starts only at the delivery date and untreated households are compared over the same aligned calendar window, then the immortal time mechanism is reduced. A remaining reduction is more consistent with a real effect of chlorination and related behaviors, though other observational biases could still remain. Under this interpretation, the evidence is more credible.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to immortal time bias. We cannot determine whether the reduction reflects a real effect of chlorination or a timing artifact without knowing how pre delivery time and episodes were handled for households that received the kit later. If pre delivery follow up was counted under the treated label, the effect can be inflated by misclassified time. If exposure started at delivery with aligned risk windows, the association is more consistent with a causal interpretation. Without this timing and coding information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This comparison can be biased by immortal time and time dependent exposure misclassification. To be labeled treated, a household must remain enrolled until the delivery visit weeks later. If the analysis attributes pre delivery follow up time to the treated label, then outcomes that occurred before exposure are being assigned to exposure. That distortion can create an apparent benefit that does not identify a causal effect of the kit. The key missing information is the rule for when treated time begins and how episodes prior to delivery are counted.
classification: Immortal time bias from defining treatment by a later event and mis-assigning earlier follow-up time.
pivotal_question: Were diarrhoea episodes occurring before the kit/training visit counted in the treated group's time at risk, or only after delivery?

scenario: A multi village NGO program subsidizes household latrine installation to reduce diarrhoeal disease. Households register in January, but construction happens on a rolling schedule depending on contractor availability, sometimes not until April or May. For a simple impact dashboard, the NGO labels a household as a latrine household if it completes installation at any time before the end of year audit, and compares the full year diarrhoea burden in children under 5 between latrine households and non latrine households. Diarrhoea burden comes from monthly caregiver recall surveys conducted from January onward. The dashboard shows that latrine households report fewer diarrhoea days. The summary does not clarify whether diarrhoea days reported before the installation date were attributed to the latrine household label for households that installed later.
claim: Household latrine installation caused fewer diarrhoea days in children under 5 over the year.
label: NO

variables.X: Classified as a latrine household based on eventual completion
variables.Y: Monthly reported under-5 diarrhoea days during the year
Z: Immortal interval from registration to installation completion

causal_structure: Households are labeled exposed based on future completion and earlier months may be attributed to the exposed label.
key_insight: When exposure is defined by a later completion date, pre completion time can be misclassified as exposed and inflate the apparent benefit.
hidden_timestamp: Whether months before installation were counted under the exposed label for households that completed installation later.

conditional_answers.if_A: If months before installation were counted under the exposed label for households that installed later, then the exposed group includes a misclassified pre installation interval. Early diarrhoea days and early dropouts can be unevenly allocated across groups, which can exaggerate the apparent protection. Under this interpretation, the reported gap can be largely methodological.
conditional_answers.if_B: If exposure begins at the installation date and outcomes are compared in aligned post installation windows or with a time to event model, then the immortal time mechanism is reduced. A remaining reduction is more consistent with a real sanitation benefit, though other observational biases could still remain. Under this interpretation, the evidence is more credible.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to immortal time bias. We cannot determine whether latrines reduced diarrhoea or whether the difference is driven by classifying households based on a future completion date without knowing how pre installation months and outcomes were handled. If pre installation months were counted as exposed, the effect can be inflated by misclassified time. If exposure started at installation with aligned follow up, the association is more consistent with a causal interpretation. Without this timing and coding information, the causal conclusion is not justified.
gold_rationale: Classifying households as exposed based on whether they complete installation by year end can embed a time misclassification problem. Households counted as exposed must remain in the program until completion, and if earlier months are attributed to exposure then outcomes that occurred before installation are assigned to exposure. That distortion can create an apparent advantage for latrine households that does not identify a causal effect. The key missing information is whether risk time and reported diarrhoea days before installation were treated as unexposed or were incorrectly attributed to the exposed label.
classification: Immortal time bias from labeling households by end-of-year installation and attributing earlier follow-up time to the exposed group.
pivotal_question: Did the NGO's analysis treat the months before latrine completion as exposed time for households that installed later, or start exposure at the installation date?

subdomain: Water supply and multiple WASH interventions
scenario: A regional government rolls out a combined WASH package across peri urban settlements. A household is considered WASH upgraded only after two steps are completed. The connection is installed and the household attends the required hygiene session to activate a maintenance subsidy. Installation dates vary widely due to permitting delays and pipe breaks. The evaluation uses clinic records of severe paediatric diarrhoea and defines the exposed group as children in households that are ever WASH upgraded during the 18 month evaluation. It compares severe diarrhoea rates over the full 18 months between ever upgraded and never upgraded households. The published summary reports a large reduction among the upgraded group. The summary does not clarify whether clinic events that occurred before a household reached upgraded status were attributed to the upgraded label for households that upgraded later.
claim: The combined standpipe-plus-hygiene package caused a large drop in severe paediatric diarrhoea compared with no upgrade.
label: NO

variables.X: Ever classified as WASH-upgraded (after installation + hygiene session)
variables.Y: Severe paediatric diarrhoea clinic visits during the evaluation window
Z: Immortal pre-upgrade interval required to reach upgraded status

causal_structure: Exposure is defined by completing future milestones and earlier follow up time may be attributed to the exposed label.
key_insight: When exposure requires future milestone completion, an ever exposed definition can misclassify pre upgrade time and create an apparent protective effect.
hidden_timestamp: Whether person time and clinic events before the actual upgrade date were attributed to the exposed label for households that upgraded later.

conditional_answers.if_A: If households were treated as upgraded for the entire 18 months once they eventually completed the milestones, then pre upgrade time is misclassified as exposed. Clinic events before upgrade would be attributed to exposure that had not yet occurred, and events can be unevenly allocated across groups. Under this interpretation, the headline reduction can be largely a time misclassification artifact.
conditional_answers.if_B: If exposure begins at the exact upgrade date and the analysis compares risk in correctly aligned post upgrade windows, then the immortal time mechanism is reduced. A remaining reduction is more consistent with a real benefit from improved supply and hygiene practices, though it would still be observational evidence. Under this interpretation, the causal interpretation is more credible.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to immortal time bias. We cannot tell whether the reduction reflects a real effect or a timing artifact without knowing how events and person time before the upgrade date were handled for households that upgraded later. If pre upgrade time was attributed to the exposed label, the effect can be inflated by misclassified time. If exposure started at the upgrade date with aligned risk windows, the evidence is more consistent with a genuine benefit. Without this timing and coding information, the causal conclusion is not justified.
gold_rationale: This design can embed immortal time and time dependent exposure misclassification because upgraded status requires completing future steps. If an ever upgraded definition is applied across the full window, then time and events before the upgrade date can be assigned to exposure even though the intervention had not yet occurred. That distortion can create an apparent protective effect that does not identify a causal impact of the package. The key missing information is whether pre upgrade person time and clinic events were treated as unexposed or were incorrectly attributed to the exposed label.
classification: Immortal time bias from using an ever-upgraded definition that requires survival to later milestones and can misclassify earlier time at risk.
pivotal_question: In the analysis, were severe-diarrhoea events and person-time before a household's actual upgrade date attributed to the upgraded group or handled as unexposed time?

scenario: After a major coastal oil spill, a state agency created a roster of "certified shoreline cleanup responders." To get certified, workers had to complete a 12-week hazardous-waste training program and pass a medical screening; only then were they eligible to be deployed on cleanup sites with heavy oil exposure and chemical dispersants. In a public report, analysts compared 5-year all-cause mortality between "certified responders" (treated as the exposed group) and other hired cleanup workers (treated as unexposed). They counted follow-up time starting on the hire date for everyone, but classified workers as "certified responders" if they ever became certified during the first year. Deaths that occurred before certification were counted in the unexposed group because those workers never reached certification. The report highlights that certified responders had noticeably lower mortality than non-certified hires.
claim: Certification and deployment as an oil-spill responder reduces 5-year mortality among cleanup workers.
label: NO

variables.X: Being classified as a certified/deployed shoreline cleanup responder (exposed status)
variables.Y: 5-year all-cause mortality after hire
Z: The required 12-week training + medical screening period before certification (immortal eligibility window)

causal_structure: T4 IMMORTAL TIME: Z is a required pre-exposure interval. Only workers who survive Z can enter X=1. Deaths during Z prevent X=1 classification, creating an immortal period if Z-time is misallocated.
key_insight: If exposure requires surviving to a later milestone, attributing pre-milestone time to the exposed group can create a fake protective effect.
hidden_timestamp: The calendar date when each worker completed training and medical screening and first became certified.

conditional_answers.if_A: If pre-certification time was counted as exposed (or exposure was defined as 'ever certified' from baseline), the certified group contains an immortal interval by construction: deaths during training cannot occur for those later labeled exposed. That will bias the estimate toward a protective effect even if certification or deployment has no benefit or increases risk. The reported lower mortality could therefore be mostly a bookkeeping artifact.
conditional_answers.if_B: If exposure was treated as time-varying and workers contributed unexposed person-time until the certification date, with deaths before certification remaining in the unexposed risk set, then the comparison no longer gives the exposed group a guaranteed survival head start. Under that design, a mortality difference could more plausibly reflect real differences after certification or deployment, though it would still require careful interpretation.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to immortal time bias. We cannot tell whether certified responders truly had lower mortality or whether they only appear safer because workers had to survive the 12-week certification window to be labeled certified. If the analysis treated exposure as starting at hire or used 'ever certified,' the apparent benefit can be an artifact. If exposure was time-updated from the certification date, the comparison is more interpretable. Without knowing how person-time and early deaths were handled, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This comparison is vulnerable to immortal time bias. By design, a worker must survive long enough to complete training and screening to be classified as exposed. If person-time from hire until certification is attributed to the exposed group, or if early deaths are systematically attributed to the unexposed group, the exposed group contains an immortal interval where the outcome cannot occur for those ultimately labeled exposed. That protected time can mechanically produce an apparent survival benefit even if certification or deployment has no causal protective effect and could even be harmful. The key ambiguity is whether the analysis treated exposure as time-varying starting at certification or incorrectly treated 'ever certified' as exposed from baseline. Because the outcome prevents certification, inclusion in the exposed group depends on surviving the eligibility window rather than on a causal effect of certification itself.
classification: Immortal time bias from defining exposure by surviving to certification.
pivotal_question: In the analysis, did follow-up time before certification count as exposed time, or did exposure start only on the certification date?

scenario: A regional conservation program hires seasonal crews to plant trees after wildfires. In response to hotter summers, the program introduced a "Heat-Ready Certification": workers attend a 7-day acclimatization and hydration training, then receive a wearable heat-alert device and are assigned to the most exposed planting sites. An internal evaluation compared rates of heat-related emergency incidents over the season between Heat-Ready certified workers and non-certified workers. The evaluation started counting person-days from the first day of employment for everyone, but classified someone as "Heat-Ready" if they completed the 7-day program at any point in their first month. Workers who fainted or were hospitalized during the first week were recorded as non-certified because they never finished the training. The report concludes that Heat-Ready certification is associated with markedly fewer heat emergencies.
claim: Heat-Ready certification causally reduces heat-related emergency incidents among wildfire reforestation workers.
label: NO

variables.X: Heat-Ready certification (training completed + device assigned) as the exposure
variables.Y: Heat-related emergency incidents during the season
Z: The 7-day acclimatization/training period required before certification (immortal eligibility window)

causal_structure: T4 IMMORTAL TIME: Z is the pre-certification interval required for X=1. Events during Z prevent X=1 labeling, so misallocating Z-time to X=1 induces a spurious protective effect.
key_insight: When early events prevent someone from becoming exposed, counting that early time under exposure can manufacture a benefit.
hidden_timestamp: The day each worker completed the 7-day program and was first classified as Heat-Ready.

conditional_answers.if_A: If days 1 through 7 were credited to the certified group or certification was assigned from the start of employment, then certified workers necessarily contribute an immortal week where a heat emergency cannot occur for them to remain classifiable as certified. That bookkeeping will bias the certified group toward fewer incidents and can fully explain an apparent protective effect.
conditional_answers.if_B: If exposure begins on the certification date and workers contribute unexposed person-days until day 7, then the certified group does not get a guaranteed incident-free head start. In that case, lower incident rates after certification could plausibly reflect real protection from the wearable alerts and training, although other design details would still matter for interpretation.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to immortal time bias. We cannot determine whether Heat-Ready certification truly lowers heat emergencies or whether certified workers look safer because they had to make it through the first 7 days without an emergency to be labeled certified. If person-days before day 7 were counted as exposed or 'ever certified' was used, the benefit could be an artifact. If exposure starts at certification and pre-certification time is unexposed, the association is more interpretable. Without clarification on how the first-week time and early incidents were handled, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This is an immortal time problem. Completing the 7-day program is a prerequisite for being labeled exposed. Workers classified as Heat-Ready must remain incident-free long enough to finish the first week. Incidents during that window either remove workers from the exposed group or prevent exposure classification. If the analysis credits the exposed group with person-days before certification or uses 'ever certified' at baseline, it creates a protected interval where the outcome is structurally impossible for those ultimately labeled exposed, yielding an artificial protective association. The ambiguity is whether exposure was treated as time-varying starting after day 7 or whether the first-week time was incorrectly included under the exposed label.
classification: Immortal time bias created by a required incident-free training window before exposure classification.
pivotal_question: Did the evaluation treat workers as exposed only after day 7, or did it count days 1 through 7 under the Heat-Ready label for those who eventually completed the program?

subdomain: Air quality regulation & industrial environmental monitoring
scenario: A country tightened greenhouse-gas reporting rules for large industrial sites. One compliance pathway is to become a "verified continuous-monitoring operator," which requires completing a year of onsite service, passing an annual medical exam, and finishing an external certification audit. Only after verification are operators assigned to the continuous-monitoring role that includes upgraded ventilation in control rooms and employer-funded respiratory screening. A labor-environment watchdog group published an analysis of worker mortality at several regulated facilities, comparing verified continuous-monitoring operators to other plant workers. Their survival curves start at the date of hire and the group label is based on whether someone ever became verified within the first 18 months. They report that verified operators have substantially lower respiratory and cardiovascular mortality over the next decade, arguing the compliance pathway improves worker health while plants decarbonize. Critics counter that the result could reflect how verification is defined and timed rather than any real protection, but the report does not describe how time before verification was treated in the exposed group's risk time.
claim: Becoming a verified continuous-monitoring operator causally lowers long-run cardiopulmonary mortality at regulated industrial facilities.
label: NO

variables.X: Verified continuous-monitoring operator status (post-verification assignment) as exposure
variables.Y: Long-run cardiopulmonary mortality after hire
Z: The required 1-year service + audit/medical process before verification (immortal eligibility window)

causal_structure: T4 IMMORTAL TIME: Z is a protected pre-exposure window required for X=1. Events during Z prevent later X=1 classification, so misclassifying Z-time as exposed induces spurious protection.
key_insight: Large protective effects can appear when exposed status is only attainable after surviving a long eligibility period.
