As a result, the observed association between residential greenness and mortality could reflect different underlying causal processes.
claim: Living near more green space reduces all-cause mortality.
label: NO

variables.X: Residential greenness
variables.Y: All-cause mortality
Z: Physical activity level

causal_structure: Either X <- Z -> Y or X -> Z -> Y
key_insight: Determining whether physical activity occurred before or after increased greenness resolves whether it confounds or mediates the association.
hidden_timestamp: Whether physical activity levels changed before residents experienced higher greenness or only after green space exposure increased.

conditional_answers.if_A: If higher physical activity levels existed before individuals lived near greener areas, then physical activity is a confounder that influenced both residential choice and mortality risk. In this case, greenness itself may not be the primary cause of reduced mortality, but rather a correlate of healthier lifestyles.
conditional_answers.if_B: If physical activity increased only after exposure to greener surroundings, then activity functions as a mediator through which green space affects mortality. Under this interpretation, greenness plausibly contributes to lower mortality by encouraging more active behaviors.

wise_refusal: The claim that green space reduces mortality is ambiguous because physical activity may act as either a confounder or a mediator. We cannot determine whether physical activity preceded exposure to green space or arose as a consequence of it without detailed temporal information. If activity levels were already higher before residents lived near green spaces, the association may reflect healthier individuals selecting greener neighborhoods. If activity increased only after green space exposure, greenness could plausibly contribute to lower mortality through behavioral changes. Without this information, the causal claim cannot be endorsed.
gold_rationale: The association between greenness and mortality is ambiguous because physical activity could either precede green space exposure or result from it, changing the causal interpretation.
classification: This is a confounder-mediator ambiguity involving an uncertain temporal role of a third variable.
pivotal_question: Did changes in physical activity occur before residents were exposed to greener environments, or only after greenness increased?

scenario: Several US cities tracked neighborhood-level outcomes after launching a street-tree planting initiative targeting "heat vulnerable" blocks. In the public dashboard, neighborhoods with higher tree-planting density (X) also show larger declines in summer heat-related ER visits (Y) over the next two years. At the same time, these same neighborhoods show increases in "neighborhood disinvestment reversal" indicators (Z): new building permits, rising rents, and a shift toward higher-income residents. Advocates argue the trees reduced local heat stress and therefore reduced ER visits. A city analyst proposes controlling for Z in a regression "to isolate the pure cooling effect of trees," since redevelopment is "obviously related to health."
claim: Planting more street trees caused the observed reduction in heat-related ER visits.
label: NO

variables.X: Street-tree planting density / canopy increase from the program
variables.Y: Change in heat-related emergency room visit rate
Z: Neighborhood redevelopment/gentrification indicators (permits, rents, income mix)

causal_structure: Either X <- Z -> Y or X -> Z -> Y (temporal ambiguity)
key_insight: Whether Z is a confounder or mediator hinges on whether redevelopment trends started before the tree initiative or accelerated after planting.
hidden_timestamp: Whether redevelopment and gentrification indicators began rising before tree planting or only after planting increased.

conditional_answers.if_A: If Z clearly rose before X, then redevelopment is a confounder: neighborhoods on an upward socioeconomic trajectory both attracted/secured more tree planting and had lower heat-related ER visits due to better housing, healthcare access, and fewer vulnerable residents. The observed X-Y association could be mostly compositional, not a cooling effect of trees.
conditional_answers.if_B: If X occurred first and Z rose afterward, then Z plausibly mediates: tree planting increased neighborhood amenities, contributing to rent increases and resident turnover. The decline in ER visits could reflect reduced vulnerability (who lives there) or other redevelopment-linked improvements, so 'adjusting for Z' would remove part of the pathway and misstate the total effect of trees.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to confounder-mediator ambiguity. We cannot tell whether redevelopment (Z) preceded tree planting (X) or was partly triggered by it without knowing when Z began changing relative to X in each neighborhood. If Z came first, it could explain both more trees and fewer ER visits; if X came first, Z could be a pathway through which ER visits changed. Without that timing information, the causal claim that trees reduced ER visits is not justified.
gold_rationale: This is confounder-mediator ambiguity (T9): Z's timing relative to X is unclear. If redevelopment/gentrification (Z) began before tree planting (X), Z can be a common cause of both X and Y (wealthier, more politically connected areas both receive/seek trees and have fewer heat ER visits). If tree planting (X) happened first, Z may be downstream of X (trees increase amenities/property values, shifting who lives there), and Z then affects Y via population vulnerability changes. Naively adjusting for Z is tempting but can be wrong: it could either appropriately block confounding (if Z is pre-X) or block part of the causal pathway / induce bias (if Z is post-X).
classification: T9 (CONF-MED): Z could be a pre-existing confounder or a post-exposure mediator.
pivotal_question: Did the redevelopment/gentrification indicators (Z) begin rising before the tree-planting rollout (X), or only after planting increased?

scenario: A state environmental agency compared river segments before and after new industrial wastewater limits aimed at reducing mercury contamination. Segments with larger reductions in permitted discharge (X) also show larger drops in mercury levels in sport fish tissue (Y) within 18-24 months. However, those same segments also experienced more intensive sediment operations (Z): channel dredging near outfalls, removal of legacy-contaminated sediments, and bank stabilization projects. Program managers argue the discharge limits worked. A consultant recommends adjusting for Z because "dredging obviously changes mercury and differs across segments," and claims the remaining association is the causal effect of discharge controls.
claim: Tighter discharge limits caused the observed decline in fish-tissue mercury.
label: NO

variables.X: Magnitude of reduction in permitted industrial mercury discharge / wastewater limits
variables.Y: Change in mercury concentration in sport fish tissue
Z: Sediment operations intensity (dredging, removal, stabilization near outfalls)

causal_structure: Either X <- Z -> Y or X -> Z -> Y (temporal ambiguity)
key_insight: The same cleanup activity Z can either explain why controls were imposed (pre-X) or be one mechanism by which controls reduced contamination (post-X).
hidden_timestamp: Whether sediment dredging and removal began before discharge limits changed or only after the new limits took effect.

conditional_answers.if_A: If Z clearly predates X, then Z is a confounder: legacy-contaminated segments prompted both stricter permitting actions and had different fish-mercury trends because of pre-existing contamination severity and earlier remediation. The observed association between X and Y could reflect targeting the worst segments, not the causal effect of discharge limits.
conditional_answers.if_B: If X predates Z, then Z is a mediator: tighter discharge limits led facilities and agencies to undertake sediment removal and related operations, which then reduced bioavailable mercury and lowered fish-tissue concentrations. In that case, adjusting for Z would remove a key pathway and could understate (or misstate) the overall effect of the discharge policy.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to confounder-mediator ambiguity. We cannot determine whether sediment operations (Z) were already underway before discharge limits (X) or were initiated as a consequence of the limits without a clear project timeline. If Z came first, it can confound the X-Y association; if X came first, Z may mediate changes in Y. Without this timing information, concluding that discharge limits caused the mercury decline is not justified.
gold_rationale: This is T9 confounder-mediator ambiguity within the required structure. Z (sediment operations) could be a confounder if it was planned/executed first: heavily contaminated segments (Z) both triggered stricter discharge actions (X) and had higher initial mercury with different subsequent trajectories in Y. Alternatively, Z could be downstream of X if discharge limits triggered compliance-driven dredging or cleanup, which then changed fish mercury (X -> Z -> Y). In that case, adjusting for Z blocks part of the causal pathway or distorts the estimated total effect. The key uncertainty is temporal ordering: did Z precede X or follow it.
classification: T9 (CONF-MED): Z may be a pre-treatment confounder or a post-treatment mediator.
pivotal_question: Were sediment dredging/removal activities (Z) initiated before the discharge-limit changes (X), or did they begin only after X took effect?

scenario: Over a decade, several western counties expanded prescribed burning on public lands (X) and also reported fewer days each fall with extreme smoke PM2.5 spikes (Y). The counties with the biggest prescribed-burn increases are also the ones showing the largest declines in an annual "late-season large-fire activity" index (Z), constructed from satellite-detected large-fire perimeters and modeled fuel consumption. A policy brief argues the prescribed burns reduced catastrophic wildfire activity, thereby reducing extreme smoke days. A skeptical reviewer counters that Z should be adjusted for because large-fire activity is an obvious driver of smoke and it varies widely year to year. The brief's authors reply that adjusting for Z is "just controlling for wildfire severity."
claim: Expanding prescribed burning caused the reduction in extreme smoke PM2.5 spike days.
label: NO

variables.X: Prescribed burning acreage / intensity (per county per year)
variables.Y: Number of days with extreme smoke PM2.5 spikes (per county per year)
Z: Annual large-fire activity index (satellite large-fire perimeters + fuel consumption)

causal_structure: Either X <- Z -> Y or X -> Z -> Y (temporal ambiguity)
key_insight: Z being a baseline risk metric vs a realized post-season fire-activity outcome creates two credible causal stories with opposite implications for adjustment.
hidden_timestamp: Whether the large-fire activity index is determined from pre-season risk conditions or calculated from end-of-season outcomes after prescribed burning decisions.

conditional_answers.if_A: If Z is effectively a pre-season risk condition, then it is a confounder: counties with lower baseline risk (or improving climate/fuel conditions) both expanded prescribed burning more easily and experienced fewer extreme smoke spikes. The X-Y association could reflect underlying risk differences and planning capacity, not a causal smoke benefit from burns.
conditional_answers.if_B: If Z is a realized post-season outcome, then it can mediate: prescribed burning reduces fuel continuity and the probability of large, high-consumption fires, lowering Z, which in turn reduces extreme smoke spikes Y. Adjusting for Z would condition on a downstream consequence of X and would not estimate the total policy effect on smoke.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to confounder-mediator ambiguity. We cannot tell whether the large-fire activity index (Z) represents pre-existing wildfire risk that drove both prescribed burning (X) and smoke spikes (Y), or whether Z is an end-of-season outcome partly caused by X. If Z is pre-X, it can confound the association; if Z is post-X, it may mediate the effect of burns on smoke. Without clarifying what Z measures and when it is determined relative to burn decisions, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This is a hard T9 confounder-mediator ambiguity because Z (large-fire activity) plays two plausible roles depending on when and how it is measured. If Z reflects pre-existing baseline risk or conditions that existed before burn decisions-such as fuel structure, ignition pressure, or drought regime summarized in planning assessments-then Z can be a common cause of both X (where managers choose to burn) and Y (where smoke spikes occur): X <- Z -> Y. But the scenario's Z is an annual post-season index that could itself be affected by prescribed burning (fuel reduction leading to fewer large fires), making Z a mediator: X -> Z -> Y. Because the same label Z can represent either baseline risk or downstream realized fire activity, naive adjustment appears reasonable yet can be invalid. The ambiguity is resolved only by knowing whether Z used here is pre-treatment (planning-time) or post-treatment (realized outcome of the season).
classification: T9 (CONF-MED): Z could be upstream risk conditions or downstream realized fire activity.
pivotal_question: Is the large-fire activity index (Z) fixed from pre-season risk assessments that guide burn planning, or is it calculated from end-of-season outcomes that could be affected by prescribed burning?

scenario: Across several agricultural sub-watersheds in a Midwestern river basin, monitoring reports show that years with higher manure applications on nearby fields (X) are followed by higher summer chlorophyll-a and more frequent nuisance algal blooms in downstream reservoirs (Y). In the same set of watersheds, routine soil testing also finds higher Mehlich-3 soil test phosphorus values (Z) on the fields that receive the most manure. A local water-quality report suggests focusing on reducing manure application rates to curb eutrophication. However, stakeholders point out that the soil-test P values could reflect a long-accumulated phosphorus surplus from earlier fertilization and concentrated livestock operations, not just current manure practices. Others argue soil P is exactly the pathway by which manure increases runoff P and fuels blooms. The dataset is annual and does not clearly show whether elevated soil-test P existed before the observed swings in manure application or emerged after them.
claim: Reducing manure applications will directly reduce algal blooms in the downstream reservoirs.
label: NO

variables.X: Manure application intensity on croplands
variables.Y: Downstream reservoir algal bloom severity (e.g., chlorophyll-a, bloom days)
Z: Soil test phosphorus (Mehlich-3) on receiving fields

causal_structure: Soil test phosphorus may be a pre-existing condition that influences both manure intensity and bloom risk. It may also be a downstream accumulation that is increased by manure and then contributes to blooms. The missing element is whether soil test phosphorus levels were already high before changes in manure application intensity.
key_insight: Soil phosphorus can be a pre-existing driver of both current manure practices and bloom risk. It can also be an intermediate accumulation that manure increases over time. The interpretation depends on timing.
hidden_timestamp: Whether soil test phosphorus levels were elevated before the increases in manure application intensity, or whether they rose only after manure intensified.

conditional_answers.if_A: If Z occurred before X, then soil P is a confounder: fields with historically high soil P (from long-term surplus and livestock density) are also the ones that apply more manure now, and high soil P independently increases P runoff and bloom risk. In that case, the manure-bloom association could be largely spurious, and cutting current manure might yield limited short-term bloom improvement unless legacy soil P is addressed.
conditional_answers.if_B: If X occurred before Z, then soil P is a mediator: increased manure application raises soil P over time, which increases dissolved/particulate P losses during storms and subsequently fuels algal blooms. In that case, reducing manure would plausibly reduce future soil P buildup and, with a lag, lower bloom severity; adjusting for Z would wrongly remove part of the pathway.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to T9 confounder mediator ambiguity about soil test phosphorus. We cannot tell whether soil test phosphorus was already elevated before manure intensity increased or whether manure intensity increased soil test phosphorus over time. If soil test phosphorus predates manure changes, it may be a common cause of both manure practices and bloom risk. If manure increases soil test phosphorus, then soil test phosphorus is part of the pathway from manure to blooms. Without the timing information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This case is T9 confounder mediator ambiguity because soil test phosphorus can play two distinct roles depending on timing. If soil test phosphorus is high before changes in manure intensity, it can influence both manure practices and bloom risk, so the association between manure and blooms may be confounded. If soil test phosphorus increases only after manure intensifies, it is a plausible intermediate state that links manure to later blooms. The annual data do not establish which came first, so the causal effect of reducing manure on blooms is not identified from this association alone.
classification: Confounder-mediator ambiguity: Z could be a pre-existing cause of both X and Y or a mediator on the pathway from X to Y.
pivotal_question: Were the high soil-test phosphorus levels (Z) already present before the increases in manure application (X), or did they rise only after manure intensified?

scenario: In a northeastern U.S. coastal watershed, agencies note that after a regional NOx-control program for power plants and vehicles (X) was rolled out, nitrate concentrations measured in several rivers draining to an estuary declined over the next few years (Y). At the same time, monitoring stations reported changes in wet deposition of oxidized nitrogen over the watershed (Z). A briefing memo summarizes the pattern as evidence that NOx controls caused river nitrate to fall and therefore reduced downstream eutrophication pressure. Critics respond that the policy was not assigned randomly: jurisdictions facing unusually high deposition and public pressure may have adopted or tightened controls earlier. Because deposition and river nitrate move with weather and regional emissions, the available summary does not clearly show whether elevated deposition preceded the policy shift or whether deposition fell only after the controls were implemented. The temptation is to treat deposition as just another covariate to adjust for, but its role depends on timing.
claim: The NOx-control program reduced river nitrate levels by cutting atmospheric nitrogen deposition.
label: NO

variables.X: Implementation/intensity of regional NOx emissions controls
variables.Y: River nitrate concentrations/export to the estuary
Z: Wet deposition of oxidized nitrogen onto the watershed

causal_structure: Wet nitrogen deposition may be a pre-policy condition that influences both the intensity or timing of NOx controls and river nitrate levels. It may also be a downstream quantity that the NOx controls reduce, which then contributes to lower river nitrate. The key uncertainty is whether deposition levels changed before the policy rollout or only after it began.
key_insight: Wet deposition can be a pre-existing driver that shapes both policy adoption and river nitrate. It can also be the pathway the policy changes to affect river nitrate. Timing determines which interpretation is consistent.
hidden_timestamp: Whether wet oxidized nitrogen deposition levels were elevated before the NOx-control program began, or whether deposition declined only after the program was implemented.

conditional_answers.if_A: If Z occurred before X, then deposition is a confounder: watersheds with higher baseline deposition had higher river nitrate and were also the ones that implemented or tightened NOx controls sooner due to visibility and pressure. In that case, the apparent post-policy nitrate decline could reflect regression toward typical conditions or concurrent regional changes, and the memo's mechanism attribution is not secure.
conditional_answers.if_B: If X occurred before Z, then deposition is a mediator: the NOx-control program reduces atmospheric oxidized-N inputs, which lowers deposition onto the watershed and subsequently lowers river nitrate export. In that case, the observed decline supports a plausible causal chain from policy to deposition to river nitrate, and adjusting for Z would incorrectly attenuate the estimated policy effect.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to T9 confounder mediator ambiguity involving wet nitrogen deposition. We cannot determine whether high deposition preceded the policy and influenced both adoption and river nitrate, or whether the policy reduced deposition and that reduction then lowered river nitrate. If deposition predates policy, the policy and nitrate association may reflect targeting of high deposition areas. If policy reduces deposition, deposition is part of the causal pathway. Without clear pre and post timing, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This case is T9 confounder mediator ambiguity because wet oxidized nitrogen deposition can plausibly come before the policy and influence both policy adoption and river nitrate levels. It can also be a downstream quantity changed by the policy that then contributes to lower river nitrate. The summary does not establish whether deposition shifts occurred before the NOx-control program or only after rollout. Because the timing is unclear, the observed association does not uniquely support the mechanism claim that the policy reduced river nitrate by cutting deposition.
classification: Confounder-mediator ambiguity: Z could be an upstream driver of both X and Y or a mediator from X to Y.
pivotal_question: Did the shift in wet oxidized-nitrogen deposition (Z) occur before the NOx-control program (X), or did deposition decline only after the program began?

scenario: A shallow recreational lake with recurring summer fish kills and poor water clarity adopts a watershed nutrient-reduction package (X): stricter fertilizer limits, manure management rules, and upgraded stormwater retention. Over the next several seasons, the lake shows gradual improvement in late-summer dissolved oxygen and transparency (Y). Monitoring teams also track internal phosphorus loading indicators (Z), such as sediment phosphorus release rates measured during anoxic periods and mid-summer soluble reactive phosphorus spikes. Two interpretations circulate. One group argues the policy worked by reducing external inputs, which in turn reduced internal recycling over time, allowing recovery. Another group notes that internal loading can remain high for years due to legacy phosphorus in sediments and that sites with the worst internal loading often received the most aggressive watershed controls first. The available summaries report co-trends in X, Y, and Z, but they do not clearly establish whether internal loading was already elevated before the policy package or whether it shifted only after the external controls took effect.
claim: The nutrient-reduction package improved lake oxygen and clarity by reducing internal phosphorus loading.
label: NO

variables.X: Adoption/intensity of watershed nutrient-reduction controls
variables.Y: Lake recovery metrics (late-summer oxygen, water clarity)
Z: Internal phosphorus loading (sediment release and soluble phosphorus spikes)

causal_structure: Internal phosphorus loading may be a pre-existing legacy condition that influences both how aggressively watershed controls are deployed and how the lake recovers. It may also be a downstream state that external controls gradually change, which then contributes to better oxygen and clarity. The missing element is whether internal loading indicators were elevated before the policy package or changed only after it began.
key_insight: Internal loading can be the reason a lake is targeted for strong controls. It can also be a process that those controls change over time. The interpretation depends on timing.
hidden_timestamp: Whether internal phosphorus loading indicators were elevated before the nutrient-reduction package was implemented, or whether they shifted only after external input controls began.

conditional_answers.if_A: If Z occurred before X, then internal loading is a confounder: lakes with high legacy sediment P are prioritized for stronger watershed controls and also have worse oxygen and clarity dynamics regardless of recent policy. The co-movement of policy intensity and later improvement could reflect concurrent drivers (weather, food-web shifts) or long natural recovery, and attributing gains specifically to an internal-loading mechanism is shaky.
conditional_answers.if_B: If X occurred before Z, then internal loading is a mediator: external nutrient controls reduce new inputs, which over time lowers sediment release and mid-summer soluble P spikes, leading to better oxygen and transparency. Under this interpretation, the package plausibly improves water quality through gradual weakening of the self-sustaining eutrophic state, and treating Z as pre-existing would mischaracterize the causal chain.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to T9 confounder mediator ambiguity about internal phosphorus loading. We cannot tell whether internal loading was already high before the policy package and influenced both intervention intensity and lake outcomes, or whether the policy changed internal loading and that change then improved oxygen and clarity. If internal loading predates the policy, the improvements may not be attributable to the proposed mechanism. If the policy changes internal loading, internal loading is part of the pathway. Without the timing information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This case is T9 confounder mediator ambiguity because internal phosphorus loading can plausibly exist at high levels before a policy package and influence both the decision to intervene and the lake recovery trajectory. It can also be a downstream state that external nutrient controls gradually reduce, which then contributes to better oxygen and clarity. The available summaries do not establish whether internal loading indicators were elevated before the intervention or whether they shifted only afterward. Because that ordering is unclear, the mechanism claim is not identified from the co-trends alone.
classification: Confounder-mediator ambiguity: Z could be a pre-policy driver of both intervention intensity and outcomes, or a mediator through which the intervention affects outcomes.
pivotal_question: Were the internal phosphorus loading indicators (Z) elevated before the nutrient-reduction package (X) was implemented, or did they shift only after external input controls began?

scenario: Using data from the 2021 China General Social Survey, a city sustainability office notices that residents who report more pro-environmental behaviors in the private sphere-like household energy conservation and recycling-also report more pro-environmental behaviors in the public sphere, such as advocating in the community, urging others to conserve energy, or supporting environmental protection in public places. The office concludes that expanding "low-barrier" private behaviors will reliably cultivate "higher-cost" public participation. They propose a campaign that heavily promotes household actions (e.g., sorting waste, reducing electricity use) as a pathway to increase public engagement. However, the evidence is observational and cross-sectional, and the same paper notes difficulty capturing time-varying behavior and the lack of longitudinal tracking, as well as the need to explore the reverse impact mechanism from public-sphere behavior back to private-sphere behavior. In this setting, it is unclear whether private actions actually lead to public actions, or whether people who are already publicly engaged adopt more private actions afterward (e.g., to align with their identity, attention, or civic commitments).
claim: Increasing residents' private-sphere pro-environmental behaviors will cause increases in their public-sphere pro-environmental behaviors.
label: NO

variables.X: Private-sphere pro-environmental behaviors (e.g., household energy conservation, recycling).
variables.Y: Public-sphere pro-environmental behaviors (e.g., community advocacy, urging conservation in public settings).
Z: Measured timing information for when each person began private-sphere behaviors versus public-sphere behaviors

causal_structure: The observed association is compatible with private-sphere behaviors increasing later public-sphere behaviors. It is also compatible with public-sphere engagement leading people to adopt more private-sphere behaviors. The direction cannot be identified without timing information.
key_insight: A correlation between private and public behaviors does not identify whether private actions cultivate public engagement or whether public engagement drives later private actions.
hidden_timestamp: Whether private-sphere behaviors typically began before public-sphere behaviors for the same individuals, or whether public-sphere behaviors began first.

conditional_answers.if_A: If private-sphere behaviors typically started first, then it is plausible that practicing low-barrier actions helped build commitment that later translated into public participation. Under this interpretation, promoting private behaviors could be a stepping stone toward broader civic engagement.
conditional_answers.if_B: If public-sphere behaviors typically started first, then the association is better explained by public engagement driving later private actions. Under this interpretation, the campaign may mostly attract people already publicly engaged, and increasing household actions would not be the causal lever for creating new public participation.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to T10 reverse causation. We cannot determine the direction between private-sphere behaviors and public-sphere behaviors without knowing which behavior reliably began first for individuals. If private behaviors began before public engagement, promoting private actions may plausibly increase later public participation. If public engagement began first, the observed pattern may reflect public participation driving later private actions. Without the timing information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This case is T10 reverse causation because the cross-sectional association is consistent with either direction between private-sphere and public-sphere behaviors. The data do not establish temporal precedence, and the setting lacks longitudinal tracking that would show which behavior started first. Without that timing, the causal direction cannot be inferred from correlation alone, so the intervention claim is not identified.
classification: Direction error via reverse causation (claimed X -> Y, but Y -> X is plausible).
pivotal_question: Did residents typically begin public-sphere pro-environmental actions before they increased private-sphere behaviors, or did the private-sphere behaviors start first?

scenario: Across several tropical regions, analyses of observational data report that protected areas tend to exhibit higher species richness than nearby unprotected lands. Conservation agencies often cite this pattern as evidence that establishing protected areas increases biodiversity. However, most protected areas were designated decades ago using criteria that favored regions already known to host high biodiversity, low human pressure, or charismatic species. Over time, biodiversity surveys expanded preferentially within these protected areas, while degraded or heavily used regions were less frequently monitored. As a result, current datasets show a strong association between protection status and biodiversity outcomes, but the temporal ordering of protection decisions and biodiversity levels is unclear. It is plausible that protection improved biodiversity through reduced land use change and exploitation. It is also plausible that areas with inherently high biodiversity were more likely to be protected in the first place, and that protection status is reacting to biodiversity rather than causing it. Without clear evidence on whether biodiversity levels increased after protection relative to pre-designation baselines, the causal direction remains ambiguous.
claim: Establishing protected areas increases local biodiversity.
label: NO

variables.X: Protected area designation
variables.Y: Observed biodiversity levels
Z: Measured biodiversity levels before protected area designation for the same sites

causal_structure: The association is compatible with protected status increasing biodiversity after designation. It is also compatible with high biodiversity leading sites to be designated as protected. The direction cannot be identified without pre-designation biodiversity measurements.
key_insight: Temporal precedence of biodiversity relative to protection status is required to distinguish protection effects from site selection effects.
hidden_timestamp: Whether biodiversity was already high before protected area designation, or whether biodiversity increased only after designation relative to a pre-designation baseline.

conditional_answers.if_A: If biodiversity was already high prior to designation, then agencies likely selected these sites because of their ecological value. In this case, protection status reflects a response to biodiversity rather than its cause. The observed association would not demonstrate a causal effect of protection on biodiversity.
conditional_answers.if_B: If biodiversity increased substantially only after protection was implemented, then reduced disturbance and land conversion plausibly led to biodiversity gains. Under this interpretation, protection would be a causal driver of improved ecological outcomes.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to T10 reverse causation. We cannot determine whether protected area designation caused biodiversity gains or whether biodiverse sites were preferentially designated without knowing biodiversity levels before designation. If biodiversity rose after protection relative to a pre-designation baseline, protection plausibly caused the increase. If biodiversity was already high beforehand, designation may have been a response to biodiversity rather than its cause. Without pre-designation biodiversity information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This case is T10 reverse causation because the observed association supports two incompatible directions. Protected area designation may increase biodiversity after designation through reduced exploitation. High biodiversity may also lead to designation because agencies choose sites that already have high ecological value. The available data do not include clear pre-designation baselines for the same sites, so temporal precedence is not established. Without that missing timing information, the causal direction cannot be identified from the association alone.
classification: This case illustrates reverse causation in the interpretation of conservation outcomes.
pivotal_question: Were biodiversity levels already high before areas were designated as protected, or did they increase only after protection was implemented?

scenario: A regional forest agency rolls out a thinning program to reduce wildfire risk across public lands. Researchers assemble an observational control-impact dataset using annual bird point-count surveys (including citizen-science checklists) and agency records of which forest stands were thinned each year. In a simple year-to-year comparison, stands that received thinning show lower songbird abundance in the following breeding season than nearby unthinned stands. A policy memo summarizes this pattern as evidence that thinning harms songbirds, and suggests scaling back thinning near important habitat. But the thinning schedule is not randomized: managers prioritize stands that look "degraded" or "at risk," and local biologists sometimes flag areas where birds have recently declined as candidates for habitat work. In other words, the observed association could reflect that declining bird abundance influences where and when thinning gets implemented, rather than thinning driving the decline. Without knowing the temporal ordering and selection timing, the direction of causality remains ambiguous.
claim: Forest thinning reduces local songbird abundance.
label: NO

variables.X: Forest thinning implementation/intensity in a stand (treatment)
variables.Y: Subsequent songbird abundance in the stand (outcome)
Z: Timing evidence about pre-treatment bird trends and the dates of treatment selection and implementation

causal_structure: T10 Reverse. The association could reflect thinning reducing birds. It could also reflect declining birds influencing which stands are selected for thinning and when thinning occurs.
key_insight: You need timing evidence showing whether bird declines started before thinning was selected or implemented, or only after thinning occurred.
hidden_timestamp: Dates of thinning selection decisions, thinning implementation, and the pre-treatment trajectory of bird abundance in each stand

conditional_answers.if_A: If thinning was selected and implemented before any decline, and bird abundance was not already trending downward, then the later drop is consistent with thinning reducing songbird abundance. The association matches the memo's interpretation, although other biases could still exist.
conditional_answers.if_B: If bird abundance was already declining before thinning was selected or implemented, then it is plausible that managers targeted struggling stands. In that case, low post-thinning counts would reflect targeting of already-declining sites rather than harm caused by thinning.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to T10 reverse causality. We cannot determine whether thinning reduced songbird abundance or whether declining songbird abundance led managers to prioritize thinning without knowing the dates of treatment selection and implementation and the pre-treatment bird trend. If thinning clearly occurred before any decline, then thinning could be the cause of lower abundance. If declines were underway before thinning was chosen, then the association can be explained by targeting. Without this timing evidence, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This is a T10 direction problem. The pattern of lower abundance after thinning is compatible with thinning reducing birds. It is also compatible with managers selecting stands for thinning because birds were already low or declining. Because thinning is not randomized, temporal precedence is the missing identifying fact. Without dates for selection, implementation, and pre-treatment trends, the observed association does not identify the causal direction.
classification: F4-T10 (Reverse causality): the outcome may be influencing the treatment.
pivotal_question: Did songbird abundance begin declining before the stand was selected/treated for thinning, or only after thinning was implemented?

subdomain: Chemical pollution (PFAS exposure via drinking water)
scenario: In the Veneto Region "Red Area," residents were exposed to PFAS through contaminated drinking water for decades until the contamination was detected and filtration was implemented. During a regional health surveillance screening round, thousands of women ages roughly 40-60 provided blood samples for PFAS measurement (e.g., PFOA, PFOS, PFHxS) and answered questions about menopausal status. When results were summarized, post-menopausal women showed substantially higher serum PFAS levels than pre-menopausal women, even after adjusting for age and other reported factors. A local public-health briefing and several media summaries framed the pattern as evidence that PFAS exposure accelerates ovarian aging and causes earlier natural menopause, urging faster remediation and expanded filtration to "prevent early menopause" in the community. However, clinicians involved in the program noted that menstruation (and related reproductive processes) can be a route of PFAS elimination, and that women who have already stopped menstruating may retain PFAS longer, potentially elevating measured serum concentrations even if their environmental exposure is similar.
claim: Higher PFAS exposure causes earlier natural menopause in the Veneto Region's exposed communities.
label: NO

variables.X: Serum PFAS concentration (e.g., PFOA/PFOS/PFHxS) at screening
variables.Y: Menopause onset / menopausal status (natural menopause timing)
Z: Timing evidence on whether PFAS levels were elevated before menopause onset, and whether menopause-related clearance changes can raise measured serum PFAS

causal_structure: T10 Reverse. The association could reflect PFAS contributing to earlier menopause. It could also reflect menopause changing PFAS elimination so that measured serum PFAS is higher after menopause.
key_insight: A cross-sectional PFAS and menopause association can reflect menopause-driven changes in PFAS clearance rather than PFAS changing menopausal timing.
hidden_timestamp: Whether PFAS concentrations were measured as elevated before the menopausal transition, and the timing of sampling relative to menopause onset

conditional_answers.if_A: If PFAS levels were already higher in samples collected while women were clearly pre-menopausal, and higher pre-menopausal PFAS predicts earlier subsequent menopause, then the association is consistent with PFAS contributing to earlier menopause. Under this interpretation, remediation that reduces exposure could plausibly reduce risk.
conditional_answers.if_B: If measured PFAS rises mainly after menopause begins because elimination pathways change when menstruation stops, then menopausal status can lead to higher serum PFAS even with similar exposure. Under this interpretation, the cross-sectional difference does not support PFAS causing earlier menopause.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to T10 reverse causality. We cannot determine whether higher PFAS preceded menopause or whether PFAS became higher after menopause because elimination changed without knowing the timing of PFAS measurements relative to menopause onset. If PFAS was elevated before the transition and predicts earlier onset, then PFAS could be a cause of earlier menopause. If PFAS increases mainly after menopause begins, then menopause can explain higher measured PFAS. Without this timing evidence, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This is a T10 direction problem. The cross-sectional association can arise if menopause changes PFAS clearance so serum PFAS increases after menstruation stops. It can also arise if higher PFAS exposure contributes to earlier menopause. The missing identifying fact is temporal precedence of PFAS levels relative to menopause onset. Without pre-transition PFAS measurements or a prospective design that anchors exposure before the outcome, the observed association does not justify the causal claim.
classification: Direction error (reverse causation): the observed pattern may reflect Y -> X rather than X -> Y.
pivotal_question: Were PFAS serum concentrations elevated before the menopausal transition (in samples collected while women were still pre-menopausal), or do they rise only after menopause begins?

scenario: Across a global network of 1 m2 grassland plots monitored repeatedly over many years, ecologists track plot-level plant species richness and aboveground live biomass (used as productivity). In several sites, years with higher observed richness tend to coincide with lower biomass, and within some plots, increases in richness over time are followed by declines in biomass. A conservation team proposes using this pattern to argue that promoting higher local plant richness will reduce grassland productivity, potentially lowering forage availability. However, richness and biomass are recorded within the same annual sampling window, and the ecological processes that change biomass (e.g., drought year, herbivory pressure, nutrient pulses) can also change competitive dominance and recruitment, which can quickly alter how many species are detectable in a 1 m2 plot. Without knowing which change comes first, the observed association could reflect productivity shifts that drive richness, rather than richness driving productivity.
claim: Increasing plant species richness causes grassland productivity to decline.
label: NO

variables.X: Plot-level plant species richness (number of species in a 1 m2 plot in a given year)
variables.Y: Plot-level productivity measured as aboveground live biomass per year (1 m2)
Z: Timing evidence about whether richness changes occur before biomass changes within the relevant seasonal window

causal_structure: T10 Reverse. The association could reflect richness reducing biomass. It could also reflect biomass changes altering which species are present or detectable, which changes measured richness.
key_insight: Because richness and biomass are co-measured within a year, a negative association can reflect either direction. The missing information is which variable changes first in time.
hidden_timestamp: Richness and biomass are recorded in the same annual sampling window. The within-season ordering of changes is not observed.

conditional_answers.if_A: If richness changes reliably occur before biomass changes, such as richness measured earlier predicting later biomass in the same plot, then it is plausible that richness contributes to lower biomass. Under this interpretation, interventions that increase richness could reduce biomass in later measurements.
conditional_answers.if_B: If biomass changes occur before richness changes, such as a low biomass period preceding a rise in detectable species, then biomass is a plausible driver of measured richness. Under this interpretation, richness is partly a response to productivity shocks, so treating richness as the cause of lower biomass is misleading.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to T10 reverse causality. We cannot determine whether richness reduced biomass or whether biomass changes altered measured richness without knowing the temporal ordering within the sampling window. If richness increases first and biomass declines afterward, then richness could be a cause of lower biomass. If biomass declines first and richness increases afterward, then biomass could be the driver of observed richness. Without this timing evidence, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This is a T10 direction problem. The claim assumes richness causes biomass to decline, but the same pattern can arise if low biomass conditions change dominance and recruitment so more species are present or detectable. Because richness and biomass are measured in the same seasonal window, temporal precedence is not identified. Without evidence that richness changes precede biomass changes, the negative association does not justify the causal claim.
classification: Direction error (reverse causation): the data do not establish whether richness causes biomass changes or biomass changes alter richness.
pivotal_question: Do changes in species richness reliably occur before changes in biomass (e.g., richness at t1 predicting biomass at t), or does prior biomass predict current richness instead?

scenario: A comparative ecology blog summarizes a large cross-species analysis of birds and notes a striking pattern: species that live in hotter regions with more unpredictable rainfall are much more likely to breed cooperatively (that is, they commonly have non-breeding helpers at nests). The blog argues this is intuitive-when droughts and heat make nesting risky, birds "respond" by evolving cooperative breeding, because helpers buffer bad years. The post points to the global association as evidence that environmental harshness drives cooperation. However, the paper's core methodological point is that a cross-species association does not reveal which evolutionary change happened first. It is possible that cooperative breeding evolved earlier under different conditions and then enabled lineages to persist and expand into hotter, more variable rainfall niches. Because transitions unfold over long time scales, simply observing that cooperative breeders are concentrated in harsh climates today does not, by itself, establish that harshness caused cooperation.
claim: Harsh, unpredictable climates cause bird species to evolve cooperative breeding.
label: NO

variables.X: Environmental harshness (hot temperatures and highly variable rainfall)
variables.Y: Cooperative breeding (presence of non-breeding helpers at nests)
Z: Evidence about the historical ordering of evolutionary transitions in cooperation and shifts into harsh climate niches

causal_structure: T10 Reverse. The association could reflect harsh climates selecting for cooperative breeding. It could also reflect cooperative breeding enabling lineages to expand into harsh climates.
key_insight: A present-day cross-species association cannot identify which transition happened first. The missing information is whether cooperation evolved before or after shifts into harsh climates.
hidden_timestamp: Phylogenetic timing of transitions in cooperative breeding relative to transitions into hotter, more variable rainfall environments

conditional_answers.if_A: If lineages tended to shift into harsh environments first and cooperative breeding evolved afterward, then ecological constraints could have selected for helping. Under this interpretation, harsh climates could be a cause of cooperative breeding.
conditional_answers.if_B: If cooperative breeding tended to evolve first and only later did those lineages expand into harsher climates, then cooperation could enable colonization and persistence in harsh environments. Under this interpretation, the association reflects cooperation shaping where lineages can live rather than harshness creating cooperation.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to T10 reverse causality. We cannot determine whether harsh climates caused cooperative breeding or whether cooperative breeding enabled occupation of harsh climates without evidence about which evolutionary transition occurred first. If shifts into harsh climates generally occurred before cooperation evolved, then harshness could drive cooperation. If cooperation generally evolved before shifts into harsh climates, then cooperation can explain the present-day concentration in harsh regions. Without this ordering evidence, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This is a T10 direction problem. A cross-species correlation between harsh climates and cooperative breeding is compatible with harshness selecting for cooperation. It is also compatible with cooperation enabling colonization and persistence in harsh environments, which would concentrate cooperative breeders in those regions today. The missing identifying fact is the phylogenetic ordering of the trait transition relative to the environmental niche shift. Without that ordering, the causal conclusion is not justified.
classification: Reverse causation (direction error): the association could reflect Y -> X rather than X -> Y.
pivotal_question: Across lineages, did cooperative breeding generally evolve before the shift into harsh (hot, variable-rainfall) environments, or after it?

subdomain: Climate impacts and species range shifts
scenario: A conservation report tracks several cooperatively breeding bird lineages that now occupy semi-arid regions where rainfall is highly variable. The report overlays current breeding-system maps with climate layers and highlights that cooperative breeders are disproportionately found in the hottest, most drought-prone areas. It argues that as climates warm and drought variability increases, populations "shift toward" cooperative breeding because helpers provide insurance against breeding failure. Field teams also note that the most climate-exposed sites tend to have the largest group sizes and the most frequent helping at nests. The report recommends prioritizing harsh-climate reserves for studying "how climate drives the evolution of cooperation." But the same pattern would also emerge if cooperative breeding is what allows populations to persist long enough to establish and expand into these marginal sites. If cooperation improves survival and recruitment under volatility, then cooperative lineages could be overrepresented in harsh climates precisely because they are the ones capable of colonizing them, even if the social system did not arise in response to harshness.
claim: Increasing drought variability is causing these birds to become cooperative breeders.
label: NO

variables.X: Drought variability / rainfall unpredictability at sites (environmental harshness)
variables.Y: Cooperative breeding (helper presence and higher helping frequency)
Z: Evidence about whether cooperative breeding was present before expansion into drought-variable sites or emerged only after drought variability increased in occupied habitats

causal_structure: T10 Reverse. The association could reflect increasing drought variability selecting for cooperative breeding. It could also reflect cooperative breeding enabling persistence and expansion into drought-variable habitats.
key_insight: Overrepresentation of cooperative breeders in harsh sites can reflect colonization and persistence filtering. The missing information is whether cooperation emerged after exposure or predated expansion into harsh areas.
hidden_timestamp: Timing of changes in drought variability relative to when cooperative breeding became common in the lineages and when they expanded into the harshest sites

conditional_answers.if_A: If drought variability increased first in the habitats these populations occupied and cooperative breeding became common only afterward, then climate could plausibly select for helping as an adaptive response. Under this interpretation, drought variability could be a cause of cooperative breeding.
conditional_answers.if_B: If cooperative breeding was already established before these lineages expanded into the most drought-variable regions, then cooperation could enable persistence and colonization under volatility. Under this interpretation, the distribution pattern reflects cooperation shaping where populations can persist rather than drought variability newly causing cooperation.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to T10 reverse causality. We cannot determine whether increasing drought variability caused cooperative breeding or whether cooperative breeding enabled persistence and expansion into drought-variable habitats without knowing which change happened first. If drought variability increased before cooperation became common, then climate could be a driver. If cooperation was present before expansion into the harshest sites, then cooperation can explain the present distribution. Without this timing evidence, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This is a T10 direction problem. A contemporary association between drought variability and cooperative breeding can arise if harsh conditions select for helping. It can also arise if cooperative breeding enables colonization and persistence in harsh environments, which would concentrate cooperative lineages in those areas. The missing identifying fact is the timing of social-system change relative to the environmental transition and range expansion. Without that timing evidence, the claim is not justified.
classification: Reverse causation (direction error): the observed pattern could reflect Y -> X rather than X -> Y.
pivotal_question: Did cooperative breeding appear in these lineages only after they experienced increased drought variability at occupied sites, or was it present before they expanded into those harsh sites?

scenario: A UK cohort study groups people into environmental "co-exposure patterns" using baseline questionnaires and geospatial metrics (e.g., air/noise pollution, green/blue space, deprivation, health behaviors). Within these patterns, researchers also measure thousands of blood proteins at baseline. In the subgroup living in higher air-and-noise areas, one inflammation-related protein (X) is elevated at baseline among participants who are later diagnosed with cardiometabolic disease (Y) during follow-up. A policy brief summarizes the result as: "this protein is a causal driver of future disease and should be targeted to prevent cardiometabolic outcomes in polluted neighborhoods." However, cardiometabolic diseases often have long prodromal periods: people may have subclinical disease processes well before diagnosis, and those early processes could plausibly raise inflammatory proteins. The observational association alone does not make clear whether the protein change comes first and contributes to disease, or whether early disease is already present and is what elevates the protein.
claim: Elevated baseline inflammatory protein levels cause later cardiometabolic disease in people exposed to high air and noise pollution.
label: NO

variables.X: Baseline level of an inflammatory blood protein (e.g., a proteomic marker elevated in high air/noise exposure subgroup)
variables.Y: Later cardiometabolic disease onset/diagnosis during follow-up (e.g., heart disease, diabetes, renal disease)

causal_structure: The claim treats elevated baseline protein as a driver of later cardiometabolic disease. A competing explanation is that early, undiagnosed cardiometabolic disease processes were already underway and elevated the protein before formal diagnosis.
key_insight: A biomarker measured at baseline can reflect earlier disease biology. The key missing information is whether cardiometabolic pathology had already begun before the baseline blood draw.
hidden_timestamp: Timing ambiguity between the baseline proteomics blood draw and the start of cardiometabolic pathology, including preclinical onset before recorded diagnosis

conditional_answers.if_A: If the protein elevation is observed before any cardiometabolic pathology begins, then it is plausible that higher baseline protein levels contribute to later disease development. In that interpretation, the association is consistent with the protein lying on a causal pathway relevant to disease risk, although observational data still does not establish a prevention effect.
conditional_answers.if_B: If cardiometabolic pathology was already present but undiagnosed at baseline, then it is plausible that early disease processes elevated the protein. In that interpretation, the protein functions as an early marker of disease activity rather than a cause, and targeting it as prevention would be a misread of the observed association.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to reverse causation (T10). We cannot determine whether baseline protein elevation drives later cardiometabolic disease or whether early, undiagnosed disease elevates the protein without knowing whether cardiometabolic pathology had begun before the baseline blood draw. If pathology had not begun and protein elevation came first, then protein elevation could plausibly contribute to later disease. If pathology had already begun before the blood draw, then protein elevation is more plausibly a consequence or early marker. Without this timing information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This is a direction problem consistent with T10. The write-up assumes baseline protein elevation drives later cardiometabolic disease. The same association can arise if cardiometabolic disease processes began earlier and elevated the protein before diagnosis. Baseline measurement precedes recorded diagnosis, but it may not precede true disease onset. Without evidence that cardiometabolic pathology had not started before protein measurement, the causal direction asserted in the claim is not identified.
classification: Direction error: the observed association may reflect reverse causation (Y -> X).
pivotal_question: Did cardiometabolic disease processes (not just recorded diagnosis) begin before the baseline protein measurement, or only after it?

scenario: A public health team links neighborhood-level environmental metrics to cardiometabolic outcomes in a large UK cohort. They note that neighborhoods that experienced the largest recent increase in green infrastructure investment (new parks, tree planting, green corridors) (X) also show higher cardiometabolic disease rates (Y) over the same multi-year window. A skeptical commentator argues: "This proves green space interventions backfire and worsen cardiometabolic health." But the city's investment program was explicitly designed to prioritize areas with the highest existing cardiometabolic burden and the steepest recent increases in diabetes and heart disease. In other words, the program may have targeted places where Y was already high or rising. With only the observed correlation between new green investment and high disease rates, it is unclear whether green investment caused worse outcomes, or whether high outcomes triggered green investment as a response policy.
claim: Increasing neighborhood green infrastructure investment causes higher cardiometabolic disease rates.
label: NO

variables.X: Neighborhood green infrastructure investment intensity (e.g., park creation/tree planting/greening spend over time)
variables.Y: Neighborhood cardiometabolic disease rate or incidence trend over the same period

causal_structure: The claim treats green infrastructure investment as causing higher cardiometabolic disease rates. A competing explanation is that high or worsening cardiometabolic burden triggered the decision to invest in green infrastructure in those neighborhoods.
key_insight: When a policy is deployed in response to worsening outcomes, the correlation can reflect a reactive allocation rather than a harmful effect. The key missing information is whether investment was assigned based on prior disease levels or trends.
hidden_timestamp: Timing ambiguity between pre-investment cardiometabolic disease levels or trends and the timing and targeting rule for green investment rollout

conditional_answers.if_A: If green investment was implemented before disease rates rose and was not allocated using prior disease levels or trends, then it is at least temporally plausible that the investment influenced cardiometabolic outcomes. Under that interpretation, the observed association would still require careful investigation and does not by itself establish harm.
conditional_answers.if_B: If neighborhoods were selected for investment because they already had high or worsening disease rates, then the more plausible explanation is that disease burden drove investment decisions. Under that interpretation, the association does not show that green infrastructure worsened health and instead reflects targeting to high-need areas.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to reverse causation (T10). We cannot determine whether green investment increased cardiometabolic disease rates or whether high disease rates prompted green investment without knowing whether the program allocated investment using prior disease levels or trends. If investment was not targeted using disease burden and came before disease rates rose, then it is plausible that investment influenced later outcomes. If investment was targeted to neighborhoods with high or rising disease, then the association reflects a reactive policy response rather than harm from green infrastructure. Without this allocation and timing information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This fits T10 because the claimed direction treats green investment as producing higher disease. A realistic alternative is that decision makers prioritized neighborhoods with high or worsening cardiometabolic burden, so disease burden preceded and helped determine investment. With only the observed co-movement over the same window, the direction is not identified. The missing information is the program timing and allocation rule relative to pre-existing disease levels and trends.
classification: Direction error: the association can be explained by reactive policy (Y -> X).
pivotal_question: Was green infrastructure investment rolled out in response to prior cardiometabolic disease levels/trends, or did it occur before those trends changed?

subdomain: Urban carbon emissions and local environmental governance
scenario: Across 270 Chinese prefecture-level cities from 2010-2020, analysts compare changes in local-government "environmental attention" (measured by how often environment-related keywords appear in annual government work reports) with changes in city-level carbon emissions. They notice that cities showing larger increases in environmental attention over a multi-year window also tend to show larger increases in total carbon emissions over the same window. A policy memo interprets this pattern as evidence that when city leaders publicly prioritise the environment, their subsequent policy mix unintentionally pushes emissions upward-for example by favouring short-term visible air-quality actions while tolerating carbon-intensive growth that supports fiscal revenue. The memo urges the central government to discourage "green rhetoric" unless paired with binding carbon constraints. However, the study period includes major shifts in China's green-development agenda and city-specific economic pressures. The timing of when emissions surge relative to when environmental attention spikes is not clearly established in the memo, and the work reports themselves are written on a fixed annual cycle.
claim: Rising local-government environmental attention causes city carbon emissions to increase.
label: NO

variables.X: Local-government environmental attention index (keyword frequency in annual work reports)
variables.Y: City-level total carbon emissions (aggregated from energy/transport/heat consumption)
Z: Timing and publication cycle of annual government work reports that determines when the attention measure is recorded

causal_structure: The claim treats increased environmental attention in government reports as driving later increases in carbon emissions. A competing explanation is that rising emissions prompted officials to emphasize the environment more in subsequent reports and messaging.
key_insight: When attention is measured from official reports on an annual cycle, worsening emissions can trigger more environmental emphasis in reporting. The key missing information is which change comes first in time within cities.
hidden_timestamp: Key ambiguity is whether emissions rose before reported environmental attention increased within the same multi-year window, given the annual work-report production cycle

conditional_answers.if_A: If reported environmental attention increased before emissions began to rise, then it is plausible that attention reflected a policy shift that was followed by a policy mix that did not constrain carbon-intensive growth. Under that interpretation, the association is consistent with attention preceding emissions growth, even though the observational pattern alone does not establish the mechanism.
conditional_answers.if_B: If emissions began to rise before reported environmental attention increased, then it is plausible that higher emissions prompted officials to signal concern and prioritize environmental language in later work reports. Under that interpretation, the association reflects a reactive response to rising emissions rather than attention causing the emissions increase.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to reverse causation (T10). We cannot determine whether environmental attention increased first or whether emissions increased first without knowing the timing of the emissions rise relative to the increase in reported attention, given the annual work-report cycle. If attention increased before emissions rose, then attention could plausibly be upstream of the policy mix associated with later emissions growth. If emissions rose first, then increased attention is more plausibly a response. Without this timing information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This is a direction ambiguity consistent with T10. The observed association between higher reported environmental attention and higher emissions can arise if emissions rose first and officials responded by emphasizing the environment more in subsequent reports. Because the attention measure is recorded on a fixed annual reporting cycle and both variables can change within the same multi-year window, temporal precedence is not established by correlation alone. Without evidence that attention increased before emissions began rising within cities, the causal claim is not identified.
classification: Reverse causation risk: city carbon emissions may be driving environmental attention rather than the reverse.
pivotal_question: Did the city's carbon emissions begin rising before the government's environmental attention increased, or did attention increase first?

subdomain: Urban air quality and government agenda-setting
scenario: Researchers track 2010-2020 outcomes for Chinese prefecture-level cities and construct a local-government "environmental attention" score from keyword frequency in annual government work reports. They also track air quality using annual average PM2.5 concentrations. They observe that cities with larger increases in environmental attention over time often show larger improvements in air quality (declining PM2.5). A media write-up concludes that city leaders' rising environmental attention is what drove the air-quality gains: once environmental language became more prominent in official reports, enforcement and clean-up actions followed, and PM2.5 fell. The article highlights the post-2015 era as a turning point and treats increased attention as an upstream cause. But the report-based attention measure is produced after cities have already experienced some conditions during the year, and PM2.5 can fall for reasons not captured in the write-up (industrial slowdowns, regional campaigns, weather variability, or upstream reductions). The write-up does not establish whether attention reliably rises before PM2.5 improvements in the relevant cities.
claim: Increasing local-government environmental attention causes PM2.5 levels to fall.
label: NO

variables.X: Local-government environmental attention index (keyword frequency in annual work reports)
variables.Y: Urban air quality (annual average PM2.5 concentration; lower is better)
Z: Timing and publication cycle of annual government work reports that determines when the attention measure is recorded

causal_structure: The claim treats increased reported environmental attention as driving later improvements in air quality. A competing explanation is that improvements in air quality came first and officials then emphasized environmental performance more in subsequent reports.
key_insight: When attention is measured from official text on an annual cycle, changes in air quality can influence what officials emphasize in later reports. The key missing information is whether attention increases before air quality improves in time.
hidden_timestamp: Key ambiguity is whether reported environmental attention increases before PM2.5 declines, given the annual work-report production cycle and potential retrospective framing

conditional_answers.if_A: If reported environmental attention increased before PM2.5 began to decline, then it is plausible that higher prioritization was followed by enforcement and clean-up actions that improved air quality. Under that interpretation, attention could be upstream of later air-quality gains, although the observational association alone is not sufficient to establish a causal effect.
conditional_answers.if_B: If PM2.5 began to decline before reported environmental attention increased, then it is plausible that improving air quality or externally driven campaigns produced results that officials later highlighted in work reports. Under that interpretation, attention is downstream of air-quality change and treating it as the cause confuses reporting emphasis with policy impact.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to reverse causation (T10). We cannot determine whether reported environmental attention rose before PM2.5 improved or whether PM2.5 improved first without knowing the timing of the changes given the annual work-report cycle. If attention rose first, it could plausibly be upstream of later enforcement that reduced PM2.5. If PM2.5 improved first, then increased attention is more plausibly a response or a way to highlight performance. Without this timing information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This is a direction ambiguity consistent with T10. The association between higher reported environmental attention and lower PM2.5 can arise if PM2.5 improvements occurred first and then influenced the emphasis officials placed on the environment in later reports. Because work reports are produced on a fixed annual schedule and may reflect retrospective framing, the timing required to establish direction is unclear. Without evidence that attention increases precede PM2.5 declines within cities, the claim is not identified.
classification: Reverse causation risk: improving air quality may increase reported environmental attention rather than attention driving air quality.
pivotal_question: Did environmental attention rise in city reports before PM2.5 began falling, or did PM2.5 fall first and then attention increased afterward?

subdomain: Climate risk, adaptive capacity, and human development
scenario: Across several flood-prone districts, analysts compare decade-long changes in two indicators: (i) adult educational attainment (measured by the share of households headed by someone with at least lower secondary schooling), and (ii) mortality per major flood event. After a sequence of catastrophic floods in the 2010s, mortality per event gradually declines through the 2030s. Over the same period, the districts show rising educational attainment as reconstruction funds expand schooling access, conditional cash transfers keep children enrolled, and families prioritize education after repeated disruptions. A report highlights that districts with the biggest gains in education are also the ones with the largest reductions in flood mortality, and argues that education improvements caused the mortality decline by increasing preparedness, risk perception, and navigation of early-warning systems. But the post-disaster timeline also makes another direction plausible: the experience of extreme flood mortality may have triggered the education push (public spending and household prioritization), so the outcome shock could be driving the "exposure" trend. The available summaries do not clearly establish which indicator moved first within districts.
claim: Rising educational attainment is causing flood mortality to fall in these districts.
label: NO

variables.X: Educational attainment / completion levels (household-head education composition)
variables.Y: Flood mortality (deaths per major flood event, over time)

causal_structure: The claim treats rising educational attainment as the driver of declining flood mortality. A competing explanation is that earlier high flood mortality and catastrophic flood experience triggered later education investment and attainment gains.
key_insight: When a major outcome shock plausibly triggers later investment and behavior change, co-movement over time does not identify the causal direction. The key missing information is which trend changed first within districts.
hidden_timestamp: Within-district timing ambiguity between the onset of education gains and the start of the decline in flood mortality after the catastrophic flood period

conditional_answers.if_A: If educational attainment began rising before flood mortality started to decline within districts, then it is plausible that education contributed to lower mortality through improved preparedness, understanding of warnings, and access to resources. Under that interpretation, the association is consistent with education being upstream of the mortality decline.
conditional_answers.if_B: If major mortality shocks occurred first and educational attainment rose afterward, then it is plausible that high flood mortality triggered education expansion through public programs and household reprioritization. Under that interpretation, education gains are downstream of earlier mortality experience, and attributing the mortality decline to education alone is not justified.

wise_refusal: The claim is ambiguous due to reverse causation (T10). We cannot determine whether rising education reduced flood mortality or whether earlier high flood mortality triggered later education gains without knowing the within-district timing of the changes. If educational attainment rose first and mortality declined afterward, then education could plausibly contribute to lower flood mortality. If mortality shocks came first and education rose as a response, then the association reflects a reactive response to disaster outcomes. Without this temporal ordering information, the causal claim is not justified.
gold_rationale: This fits T10 because the claim assumes education drives lower flood mortality, but a plausible alternative is that earlier catastrophic flood mortality prompted education investment and higher attainment later. Both indicators evolve over time with lags, so parallel trends over a long window do not establish direction. The missing information is whether education gains were already underway before mortality began to decline within districts, or whether mortality shocks preceded and helped cause later education expansion. Without that ordering, the asserted causal direction is not identified.
classification: Reverse causation risk: flood mortality shocks may be driving subsequent education gains rather than education driving mortality declines.
pivotal_question: Within districts, did educational attainment rise before flood mortality began to decline, or did major mortality shocks occur first and the education gains follow?

scenario: In a set of rapidly industrializing states, officials track two trends from 2010 to 2050: (i) secondary-school completion rises steadily as successive cohorts age into the labor force, and (ii) energy-related CO2 emissions rise sharply as manufacturing expands. The emissions surge becomes visible around the same time governments announce large education investments and teacher hiring programs, justified by "skills for green growth."
